dn17:1.1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā kusinārāyaṃ viharati upavattane mallānaṃ sālavane antarena yamakasālānaṃ parinibbānasamaye.
dn17:1.1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying between a pair of sal trees in the sal forest of the Mallas at Upavattana near Kusinārā at the time of his full extinguishment.
dn17:1.1.2.comm: Picking up the story of the Buddha’s past life as King Mahāsudassana from DN 16:5.17.1.

dn17:1.2.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmā ānando yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho āyasmā ānando bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
dn17:1.2.1.eng: Then Venerable Ānanda went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him,

dn17:1.2.2.pli: “mā, bhante, bhagavā imasmiṃ khuddakanagarake ujjaṅgalanagarake sākhānagarake parinibbāyi.
dn17:1.2.2.eng: “Sir, please don’t be fully extinguished in this little hamlet, this jungle hamlet, this branch hamlet.

dn17:1.2.3.eng: There are other great cities such as

dn17:1.2.4.pli: Seyyathidaṃ—campā, rājagahaṃ, sāvatthi, sāketaṃ, kosambī, bārāṇasī;
dn17:1.2.4.eng: Campā, Rājagaha, Sāvatthī, Sāketa, Kosambī, and Varanasi.

dn17:1.2.5.eng: Let the Buddha be fully extinguished there.

dn17:1.2.6.pli: Ettha bahū khattiyamahāsālā brāhmaṇamahāsālā gahapatimahāsālā tathāgate abhippasannā, te tathāgatassa sarīrapūjaṃ karissantī”ti.
dn17:1.2.6.eng: There are many well-to-do aristocrats, brahmins, and householders there who are devoted to the Buddha. They will perform the rites of venerating the Realized One’s corpse.”

dn17:1.3.1.pli: “Mā hevaṃ, ānanda, avaca; mā hevaṃ, ānanda, avaca:
dn17:1.3.1.eng: “Don’t say that, Ānanda! Don’t say that

dn17:1.3.2.eng: this is a little hamlet, a jungle hamlet, a branch hamlet.

dn17:1.3.4.pli: Bhūtapubbaṃ, ānanda, rājā mahāsudassano nāma ahosi khattiyo muddhāvasitto cāturanto vijitāvī janapadatthāvariyappatto.
dn17:1.3.4.eng: Once upon a time there was a king named Mahāsudassana whose dominion extended to all four sides, and who achieved stability in the country.

dn17:1.3.5.pli: Rañño, ānanda, mahāsudassanassa ayaṃ kusinārā kusāvatī nāma rājadhānī ahosi.
dn17:1.3.5.eng: His capital was this Kusinārā, which at the time was named Kusāvatī.

dn17:1.3.6.pli: Puratthimena ca pacchimena ca dvādasayojanāni āyāmena, uttarena ca dakkhiṇena ca sattayojanāni vitthārena.
dn17:1.3.6.eng: It stretched for twelve leagues from east to west, and seven leagues from north to south.

dn17:1.3.7.pli: Kusāvatī, ānanda, rājadhānī iddhā ceva ahosi phītā ca bahujanā ca ākiṇṇamanussā ca subhikkhā ca.
dn17:1.3.7.eng: The royal capital of Kusāvatī was successful, prosperous, populous, full of people, with plenty of food.

dn17:1.3.8.pli: Seyyathāpi, ānanda, devānaṃ āḷakamandā nāma rājadhānī iddhā ceva hoti phītā ca bahujanā ca ākiṇṇayakkhā ca subhikkhā ca;
dn17:1.3.8.eng: It was just like Āḷakamandā, the royal capital of the gods, which is successful, prosperous, populous, full of spirits, with plenty of food.

dn17:1.3.9.pli: evameva kho, ānanda, kusāvatī rājadhānī iddhā ceva ahosi phītā ca bahujanā ca ākiṇṇamanussā ca subhikkhā ca.

dn17:1.3.10.pli: Kusāvatī, ānanda, rājadhānī dasahi saddehi avivittā ahosi divā ceva rattiñca, seyyathidaṃ—
dn17:1.3.10.eng: Kusāvatī was never free of ten sounds by day or night, namely:

dn17:1.3.11.pli: hatthisaddena assasaddena rathasaddena bherisaddena mudiṅgasaddena vīṇāsaddena gītasaddena saṅkhasaddena sammasaddena pāṇitāḷasaddena ‘asnātha pivatha khādathā’ti dasamena saddena.
dn17:1.3.11.eng: the sound of elephants, horses, chariots, drums, clay drums, arched harps, singing, horns, gongs, and handbells; and the cry, ‘Eat, drink, be merry!’ as the tenth.

dn17:1.4.1.pli: Kusāvatī, ānanda, rājadhānī sattahi pākārehi parikkhittā ahosi.
dn17:1.4.1.eng: Kusāvatī was encircled by seven ramparts:
dn17:1.4.1.comm: From here we leave DN 16 behind and with it any semblance of realism. Some of these details are shared with SN 22.96, which however does not mention the name Mahāsudassana.

dn17:1.4.2.pli: Eko pākāro sovaṇṇamayo, eko rūpiyamayo, eko veḷuriyamayo, eko phalikamayo, eko lohitaṅkamayo, eko masāragallamayo, eko sabbaratanamayo.
dn17:1.4.2.eng: one made of gold, one made of silver, one made of beryl, one made of crystal, one made of ruby, one made of emerald, and one made of all precious things.

dn17:1.5.1.pli: Kusāvatiyā, ānanda, rājadhāniyā catunnaṃ vaṇṇānaṃ dvārāni ahesuṃ.

dn17:1.5.2.pli: Ekaṃ dvāraṃ sovaṇṇamayaṃ, ekaṃ rūpiyamayaṃ, ekaṃ veḷuriyamayaṃ, ekaṃ phalikamayaṃ.
dn17:1.5.2.eng: made of gold, silver, beryl, and crystal.

dn17:1.5.3.pli: Ekekasmiṃ dvāre satta satta esikā nikhātā ahesuṃ tiporisaṅgā tiporisanikhātā dvādasaporisā ubbedhena.
dn17:1.5.3.eng: At each gate there were seven pillars, three fathoms deep and four fathoms high,
dn17:1.5.3.comm: Readings vary. The Sanskrit text has saptapauruṣā ardhacaturthapauruṣāś ca nikhātā.

dn17:1.5.4.pli: Ekā esikā sovaṇṇamayā, ekā rūpiyamayā, ekā veḷuriyamayā, ekā phalikamayā, ekā lohitaṅkamayā, ekā masāragallamayā, ekā sabbaratanamayā.
dn17:1.5.4.eng: made of gold, silver, beryl, crystal, ruby, emerald, and all precious things.

dn17:1.6.1.pli: Kusāvatī, ānanda, rājadhānī sattahi tālapantīhi parikkhittā ahosi.
dn17:1.6.1.eng: It was surrounded by seven rows of palm trees,

dn17:1.6.2.pli: Ekā tālapanti sovaṇṇamayā, ekā rūpiyamayā, ekā veḷuriyamayā, ekā phalikamayā, ekā lohitaṅkamayā, ekā masāragallamayā, ekā sabbaratanamayā.
dn17:1.6.2.eng: made of gold, silver, beryl, crystal, ruby, emerald, and all precious things.

dn17:1.6.3.pli: Sovaṇṇamayassa tālassa sovaṇṇamayo khandho ahosi, rūpiyamayāni pattāni ca phalāni ca.
dn17:1.6.3.eng: The golden palms had trunks of gold, and leaves and fruits of silver.

dn17:1.6.4.pli: Rūpiyamayassa tālassa rūpiyamayo khandho ahosi, sovaṇṇamayāni pattāni ca phalāni ca.
dn17:1.6.4.eng: The silver palms had trunks of silver, and leaves and fruits of gold.

dn17:1.6.5.pli: Veḷuriyamayassa tālassa veḷuriyamayo khandho ahosi, phalikamayāni pattāni ca phalāni ca.
dn17:1.6.5.eng: The beryl palms had trunks of beryl, and leaves and fruits of crystal.

dn17:1.6.6.pli: Phalikamayassa tālassa phalikamayo khandho ahosi, veḷuriyamayāni pattāni ca phalāni ca.
dn17:1.6.6.eng: The crystal palms had trunks of crystal, and leaves and fruits of beryl.

dn17:1.6.7.pli: Lohitaṅkamayassa tālassa lohitaṅkamayo khandho ahosi, masāragallamayāni pattāni ca phalāni ca.
dn17:1.6.7.eng: The ruby palms had trunks of ruby, and leaves and fruits of emerald.

dn17:1.6.8.pli: Masāragallamayassa tālassa masāragallamayo khandho ahosi, lohitaṅkamayāni pattāni ca phalāni ca.
dn17:1.6.8.eng: The emerald palms had trunks of emerald, and leaves and fruits of ruby.

dn17:1.6.9.pli: Sabbaratanamayassa tālassa sabbaratanamayo khandho ahosi, sabbaratanamayāni pattāni ca phalāni ca.
dn17:1.6.9.eng: The palms of all precious things had trunks of all precious things, and leaves and fruits of all precious things.

dn17:1.6.10.pli: Tāsaṃ kho panānanda, tālapantīnaṃ vāteritānaṃ saddo ahosi vaggu ca rajanīyo ca khamanīyo ca madanīyo ca.
dn17:1.6.10.eng: When those rows of palm trees were blown by the wind they sounded graceful, tantalizing, sensuous, lovely, and intoxicating,

dn17:1.6.11.pli: Seyyathāpi, ānanda, pañcaṅgikassa tūriyassa suvinītassa suppaṭitāḷitassa sukusalehi samannāhatassa saddo hoti vaggu ca rajanīyo ca khamanīyo ca madanīyo ca;
dn17:1.6.11.eng: like a quintet made up of skilled musicians who had practiced well and kept excellent rhythm.

dn17:1.6.12.pli: evameva kho, ānanda, tāsaṃ tālapantīnaṃ vāteritānaṃ saddo ahosi vaggu ca rajanīyo ca khamanīyo ca madanīyo ca.

dn17:1.6.13.pli: Ye kho panānanda, tena samayena kusāvatiyā rājadhāniyā dhuttā ahesuṃ soṇḍā pipāsā, te tāsaṃ tālapantīnaṃ vāteritānaṃ saddena paricāresuṃ.
dn17:1.6.13.eng: And any addicts, carousers, or drunkards in Kusāvatī at that time were entertained by that sound.
dn17:1.6.13.comm: I think the point is that they listened to the music rather than doing bad things.

dn17:1.7.1.pli: Rājā, ānanda, mahāsudassano sattahi ratanehi samannāgato ahosi catūhi ca iddhīhi.
dn17:1.7.1.eng: King Mahāsudassana possessed seven treasures and four blessings.

dn17:1.7.3.pli: Idhānanda, rañño mahāsudassanassa tadahuposathe pannarase sīsaṃnhātassa uposathikassa uparipāsādavaragatassa
dn17:1.7.3.eng: On a fifteenth day sabbath, King Mahāsudassana had bathed his head and gone upstairs in the royal longhouse to observe the sabbath.
dn17:1.7.3.comm: This is specific instance, so I use past tense. Where it is an abstract description of a legendary past, I use the present tense to denote an eternal or mythic present.

dn17:1.7.4.pli: dibbaṃ cakkaratanaṃ pāturahosi sahassāraṃ sanemikaṃ sanābhikaṃ sabbākāraparipūraṃ.
dn17:1.7.4.eng: And the heavenly wheel-treasure appeared to him, with a thousand spokes, with rim and hub, complete in every detail.
dn17:1.7.4.comm: The wheel is firstly the sun and secondly the wheel of the chariots that drove the Indo-Europeans in their conquests. It is the manifestation of unstoppable power. The solar imagery is reflected in the name Mahāsudassana (“Great Splendor”). The whole story reflects the Indo-European dream of universal domination.

dn17:1.7.6.pli: ‘sutaṃ kho pana metaṃ: “yassa rañño khattiyassa muddhāvasittassa tadahuposathe pannarase sīsaṃnhātassa uposathikassa uparipāsādavaragatassa dibbaṃ cakkaratanaṃ pātubhavati sahassāraṃ sanemikaṃ sanābhikaṃ sabbākāraparipūraṃ, so hoti rājā cakkavattī”ti.
dn17:1.7.6.eng: ‘I have heard that when the heavenly wheel-treasure appears to a king in this way, he becomes a wheel-turning monarch.

dn17:1.7.7.pli: Assaṃ nu kho ahaṃ rājā cakkavattī’ti.
dn17:1.7.7.eng: Am I then a wheel-turning monarch?’

dn17:1.8.1.pli: Atha kho, ānanda, rājā mahāsudassano uṭṭhāyāsanā ekaṃsaṃ uttarāsaṅgaṃ karitvā vāmena hatthena suvaṇṇabhiṅkāraṃ gahetvā dakkhiṇena hatthena cakkaratanaṃ abbhukkiri:
dn17:1.8.1.eng: Then King Mahāsudassana, rising from his seat and arranging his robe over one shoulder, took a ceremonial vase in his left hand and besprinkled the wheel-treasure with his right hand, saying:
dn17:1.8.1.comm: Many of the details in this myth echo the Brahmanical horse sacrifice. Since the horse was the primary source of Indo-European dominion, its sacrifice served to authorize the power of a king. It was a costly and dangerous rite that was attempted only by the greatest of sovereigns. | Bhiṅkāra (“ceremonial vase”) and abbhukkirati (“besprinkled”) are elevated terms.

dn17:1.8.2.eng: ‘Roll forth, O wheel-treasure! Triumph, O wheel-treasure!’

dn17:1.8.3.pli: Atha kho taṃ, ānanda, cakkaratanaṃ puratthimaṃ disaṃ pavatti, anvadeva rājā mahāsudassano saddhiṃ caturaṅginiyā senāya, yasmiṃ kho panānanda, padese cakkaratanaṃ patiṭṭhāsi, tattha rājā mahāsudassano vāsaṃ upagacchi saddhiṃ caturaṅginiyā senāya.
dn17:1.8.3.eng: Then the wheel-treasure rolled towards the east. And the king followed it together with his army of four divisions. In whatever place the wheel-treasure stood still, there the king came to stay together with his army.
dn17:1.8.3.comm: In the horse sacrifice, the horse is released for a year, while the king follows it with his army, claiming any land that it wanders on as his.

dn17:1.9.1.pli: Ye kho panānanda, puratthimāya disāya paṭirājāno, te rājānaṃ mahāsudassanaṃ upasaṅkamitvā evamāhaṃsu:
dn17:1.9.1.eng: And any opposing rulers of the eastern quarter came to him and said,

dn17:1.9.2.pli: ‘ehi kho, mahārāja, svāgataṃ te, mahārāja, sakaṃ te, mahārāja, anusāsa, mahārājā’ti.
dn17:1.9.2.eng: ‘Come, great king! Welcome, great king! We are yours, great king, instruct us.’

dn17:1.9.4.pli: ‘pāṇo na hantabbo, adinnaṃ na ādātabbaṃ, kāmesu micchā na caritabbā, musā na bhaṇitabbā, majjaṃ na pātabbaṃ, yathābhuttañca bhuñjathā’ti.
dn17:1.9.4.eng: ‘Do not kill living creatures. Do not steal. Do not commit sexual misconduct. Do not lie. Do not drink liquor. Maintain the current level of taxation.’
dn17:1.9.4.comm: Read bhuñjati at MN 98:10.30 with yathābhuttañca bhuñjatha at DN 17:1.9.4, DN 26:6.7, and MN 129:35.7. These have sometimes been rendered “eat”, “enjoy”, or “govern”. But compare the archaic English “use” meaning “the benefit or profit of lands”. Thus yathābhuttañca bhuñjatha means “use as has been used”, i.e. “maintain the current level of taxation”.

dn17:1.9.5.pli: Ye kho panānanda, puratthimāya disāya paṭirājāno, te rañño mahāsudassanassa anuyantā ahesuṃ.
dn17:1.9.5.eng: And so the opposing rulers of the eastern quarter became his vassals.

dn17:1.10.1.pli: Atha kho taṃ, ānanda, cakkaratanaṃ puratthimaṃ samuddaṃ ajjhogāhetvā paccuttaritvā dakkhiṇaṃ disaṃ pavatti …pe…
dn17:1.10.1.eng: Then the wheel-treasure, having plunged into the eastern ocean and emerged again, rolled towards the south. …
dn17:1.10.1.comm: The Wheel plunges into the seas, while the sacrificial horse is born in the western and eastern seas (Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa 10.6.4.1).

dn17:1.10.2.pli: dakkhiṇaṃ samuddaṃ ajjhogāhetvā paccuttaritvā pacchimaṃ disaṃ pavatti …pe…
dn17:1.10.2.eng: Having plunged into the southern ocean and emerged again, it rolled towards the west. …

dn17:1.10.3.pli: pacchimaṃ samuddaṃ ajjhogāhetvā paccuttaritvā uttaraṃ disaṃ pavatti, anvadeva rājā mahāsudassano saddhiṃ caturaṅginiyā senāya.
dn17:1.10.3.eng: Having plunged into the western ocean and emerged again, it rolled towards the north, followed by the king together with his army of four divisions.

dn17:1.10.4.pli: Yasmiṃ kho panānanda, padese cakkaratanaṃ patiṭṭhāsi, tattha rājā mahāsudassano vāsaṃ upagacchi saddhiṃ caturaṅginiyā senāya.
dn17:1.10.4.eng: In whatever place the wheel-treasure stood still, there the king came to stay together with his army.

dn17:1.10.5.pli: Ye kho panānanda, uttarāya disāya paṭirājāno, te rājānaṃ mahāsudassanaṃ upasaṅkamitvā evamāhaṃsu:
dn17:1.10.5.eng: And any opposing rulers of the northern quarter came to him and said,

dn17:1.10.6.pli: ‘ehi kho, mahārāja, svāgataṃ te, mahārāja, sakaṃ te, mahārāja, anusāsa, mahārājā’ti.
dn17:1.10.6.eng: ‘Come, great king! Welcome, great king! We are yours, great king, instruct us.’

dn17:1.10.8.pli: ‘pāṇo na hantabbo, adinnaṃ na ādātabbaṃ, kāmesu micchā na caritabbā, musā na bhaṇitabbā, majjaṃ na pātabbaṃ, yathābhuttañca bhuñjathā’ti.
dn17:1.10.8.eng: ‘Do not kill living creatures. Do not steal. Do not commit sexual misconduct. Do not lie. Do not drink liquor. Maintain the current level of taxation.’

dn17:1.10.9.pli: Ye kho panānanda, uttarāya disāya paṭirājāno, te rañño mahāsudassanassa anuyantā ahesuṃ.
dn17:1.10.9.eng: And so the opposing rulers of the northern quarter became his vassals.
dn17:1.10.9.comm: Historically, India has usually been divided into squabbling realms, but from an early age there was a dream of a unified and peaceful continent.

dn17:1.11.1.pli: Atha kho taṃ, ānanda, cakkaratanaṃ samuddapariyantaṃ pathaviṃ abhivijinitvā kusāvatiṃ rājadhāniṃ paccāgantvā rañño mahāsudassanassa antepuradvāre atthakaraṇapamukhe akkhāhataṃ maññe aṭṭhāsi rañño mahāsudassanassa antepuraṃ upasobhayamānaṃ.
dn17:1.11.1.eng: And then the wheel-treasure, having triumphed over this land surrounded by ocean, returned to the royal capital. There it stood still by the gate to the royal compound at the High Court as if fixed to an axle, illuminating the royal compound.
dn17:1.11.1.comm: “At the High Court” is uncertain. Read aḍḍa (variants attha, aṭṭa) which in Sanskrit has the senses “solve, infer, argue, discern”. The commentary interprets aḍḍakaraṇa as the “place of judgement” i.e. the court, which is clearly the case here (see also SN 3.7:1.5, MN 89:13.3). The affix -pamukha here does not mean “entrance”. Rather, it describes the attributes of a wheel-turning monarch in the sense of “finest” (eg. DN 17:2.5.1).

dn17:1.11.2.pli: Rañño, ānanda, mahāsudassanassa evarūpaṃ cakkaratanaṃ pāturahosi.
dn17:1.11.2.eng: Such is the wheel-treasure that appeared to King Mahāsudassana.

dn17:1.12.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, ānanda, rañño mahāsudassanassa hatthiratanaṃ pāturahosi
dn17:1.12.1.eng: Next, the elephant-treasure appeared to King Mahāsudassana.

dn17:1.12.2.pli: sabbaseto sattappatiṭṭho iddhimā vehāsaṅgamo uposatho nāma nāgarājā.
dn17:1.12.2.eng: It was an all-white sky-walker with psychic power, touching the ground in seven places, a king of elephants named Sabbath.
dn17:1.12.2.comm: The white elephant is a symbol of royalty to this day. The description anticipates the elephant Indra acquired in later legends, Airāvata the “cloudy”, white and huge and moving through the sky. | For sattappatiṭṭho, the commentary has susaṇṭhitaaṅgapaccaṅga (“well-grounded on each and every limb”), a sense confirmed by the Mūlasarvāstivāda Bhaiṣajyavastu which has saptāṅgaḥ supratiṣṭhito (“well-established on seven limbs”). The subcommentary lists the four feet, trunk, tail, and penis (varaṅga).

dn17:1.12.3.pli: Taṃ disvā rañño mahāsudassanassa cittaṃ pasīdi:
dn17:1.12.3.eng: Seeing him, the king was impressed,

dn17:1.12.4.pli: ‘bhaddakaṃ vata bho hatthiyānaṃ, sace damathaṃ upeyyā’ti.
dn17:1.12.4.eng: ‘This would truly be a fine elephant vehicle, if he would submit to taming.’

dn17:1.12.5.pli: Atha kho taṃ, ānanda, hatthiratanaṃ—seyyathāpi nāma gandhahatthājāniyo dīgharattaṃ suparidanto; evameva damathaṃ upagacchi.
dn17:1.12.5.eng: Then the elephant-treasure submitted to taming, as if he was a fine thoroughbred elephant that had been tamed for a long time.

dn17:1.12.6.pli: Bhūtapubbaṃ, ānanda, rājā mahāsudassano tameva hatthiratanaṃ vīmaṃsamāno pubbaṇhasamayaṃ abhiruhitvā samuddapariyantaṃ pathaviṃ anuyāyitvā kusāvatiṃ rājadhāniṃ paccāgantvā pātarāsamakāsi.
dn17:1.12.6.eng: Once it so happened that King Mahāsudassana, testing that same elephant-treasure, mounted him in the morning and traversed the land surrounded by ocean before returning to the royal capital in time for breakfast.

dn17:1.12.7.pli: Rañño, ānanda, mahāsudassanassa evarūpaṃ hatthiratanaṃ pāturahosi.
dn17:1.12.7.eng: Such is the elephant-treasure that appeared to King Mahāsudassana.

dn17:1.13.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, ānanda, rañño mahāsudassanassa assaratanaṃ pāturahosi
dn17:1.13.1.eng: Next, the horse-treasure appeared to King Mahāsudassana.

dn17:1.13.2.pli: sabbaseto kāḷasīso muñjakeso iddhimā vehāsaṅgamo valāhako nāma assarājā.
dn17:1.13.2.eng: It was an all-white sky-walker with psychic power, with head of black and mane like woven reeds, a royal steed named Thundercloud.
dn17:1.13.2.comm: The sacrificial horse is likewise white with black head or forequarters. It is identified with the sun, thus being a “sky-walker”. “Thundercloud” (valāhaka; Sanskrit balāhaka) is the name of one of the four horses of Kṛṣṇa’s chariot in the Mahābharata. The description here also recalls the Vedic sacred horse Uccaiḥśravas.

dn17:1.13.3.pli: Taṃ disvā rañño mahāsudassanassa cittaṃ pasīdi:
dn17:1.13.3.eng: Seeing him, the king was impressed,

dn17:1.13.4.pli: ‘bhaddakaṃ vata bho assayānaṃ sace damathaṃ upeyyā’ti.
dn17:1.13.4.eng: ‘This would truly be a fine horse vehicle, if he would submit to taming.’

dn17:1.13.5.pli: Atha kho taṃ, ānanda, assaratanaṃ seyyathāpi nāma bhaddo assājāniyo dīgharattaṃ suparidanto; evameva damathaṃ upagacchi.
dn17:1.13.5.eng: Then the horse-treasure submitted to taming, as if he was a fine thoroughbred horse that had been tamed for a long time.

dn17:1.13.6.pli: Bhūtapubbaṃ, ānanda, rājā mahāsudassano tameva assaratanaṃ vīmaṃsamāno pubbaṇhasamayaṃ abhiruhitvā samuddapariyantaṃ pathaviṃ anuyāyitvā kusāvatiṃ rājadhāniṃ paccāgantvā pātarāsamakāsi.
dn17:1.13.6.eng: Once it so happened that King Mahāsudassana, testing that same horse-treasure, mounted him in the morning and traversed the land surrounded by ocean before returning to the royal capital in time for breakfast.

dn17:1.13.7.pli: Rañño, ānanda, mahāsudassanassa evarūpaṃ assaratanaṃ pāturahosi.
dn17:1.13.7.eng: Such is the horse-treasure that appeared to King Mahāsudassana.

dn17:1.14.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, ānanda, rañño mahāsudassanassa maṇiratanaṃ pāturahosi.
dn17:1.14.1.eng: Next, the jewel-treasure appeared to King Mahāsudassana.

dn17:1.14.2.pli: So ahosi maṇi veḷuriyo subho jātimā aṭṭhaṃso suparikammakato accho vippasanno anāvilo sabbākārasampanno.
dn17:1.14.2.eng: It was a beryl gem that was naturally lustrous, eight-faceted, well-worked, transparent, clear, and unclouded, endowed with all good qualities.

dn17:1.14.3.pli: Tassa kho panānanda, maṇiratanassa ābhā samantā yojanaṃ phuṭā ahosi.
dn17:1.14.3.eng: And the radiance of that jewel spread all-round for a league.

dn17:1.14.4.pli: Bhūtapubbaṃ, ānanda, rājā mahāsudassano tameva maṇiratanaṃ vīmaṃsamāno caturaṅginiṃ senaṃ sannayhitvā maṇiṃ dhajaggaṃ āropetvā rattandhakāratimisāya pāyāsi.
dn17:1.14.4.eng: Once it so happened that King Mahāsudassana, testing that same jewel-treasure, mobilized his army of four divisions and, with the jewel hoisted on his banner, set out in the dark of the night.

dn17:1.14.5.pli: Ye kho panānanda, samantā gāmā ahesuṃ, te tenobhāsena kammante payojesuṃ divāti maññamānā.
dn17:1.14.5.eng: Then the villagers around them set off to work, thinking that it was day.

dn17:1.14.6.pli: Rañño, ānanda, mahāsudassanassa evarūpaṃ maṇiratanaṃ pāturahosi.
dn17:1.14.6.eng: Such is the jewel-treasure that appeared to King Mahāsudassana.

dn17:1.15.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, ānanda, rañño mahāsudassanassa itthiratanaṃ pāturahosi
dn17:1.15.1.eng: Next, the woman-treasure appeared to King Mahāsudassana.

dn17:1.15.2.pli: abhirūpā dassanīyā pāsādikā paramāya vaṇṇapokkharatāya samannāgatā nātidīghā nātirassā nātikisā nātithūlā nātikāḷikā nāccodātā atikkantā mānusivaṇṇaṃ appattā dibbavaṇṇaṃ.
dn17:1.15.2.eng: She was attractive, good-looking, lovely, of surpassing beauty. She was neither too tall nor too short; neither too thin nor too fat; neither too dark nor too light. She outdid human beauty without reaching heavenly beauty.

dn17:1.15.3.pli: Tassa kho panānanda, itthiratanassa evarūpo kāyasamphasso hoti, seyyathāpi nāma tūlapicuno vā kappāsapicuno vā.
dn17:1.15.3.eng: And her touch was like a tuft of cotton-wool or kapok.

dn17:1.15.4.pli: Tassa kho panānanda, itthiratanassa sīte uṇhāni gattāni honti, uṇhe sītāni.
dn17:1.15.4.eng: When it was cool her limbs were warm, and when it was warm her limbs were cool.

dn17:1.15.5.pli: Tassa kho panānanda, itthiratanassa kāyato candanagandho vāyati, mukhato uppalagandho.
dn17:1.15.5.eng: The fragrance of sandal floated from her body, and lotus from her mouth.

dn17:1.15.6.pli: Taṃ kho panānanda, itthiratanaṃ rañño mahāsudassanassa pubbuṭṭhāyinī ahosi pacchānipātinī kiṅkārapaṭissāvinī manāpacārinī piyavādinī.
dn17:1.15.6.eng: She got up before the king and went to bed after him, and was obliging, behaving nicely and speaking politely.

dn17:1.15.7.pli: Taṃ kho panānanda, itthiratanaṃ rājānaṃ mahāsudassanaṃ manasāpi no aticari, kuto pana kāyena.
dn17:1.15.7.eng: The woman-treasure did not betray the wheel-turning monarch even in thought, still less in deed.

dn17:1.15.8.pli: Rañño, ānanda, mahāsudassanassa evarūpaṃ itthiratanaṃ pāturahosi.
dn17:1.15.8.eng: Such is the woman-treasure that appeared to King Mahāsudassana.

dn17:1.16.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, ānanda, rañño mahāsudassanassa gahapatiratanaṃ pāturahosi.
dn17:1.16.1.eng: Next, the householder-treasure appeared to King Mahāsudassana.

dn17:1.16.2.pli: Tassa kammavipākajaṃ dibbacakkhu pāturahosi yena nidhiṃ passati sassāmikampi assāmikampi.
dn17:1.16.2.eng: The power of clairvoyance manifested in him as a result of past deeds, by which he sees treasure troves, both owned and ownerless.

dn17:1.16.3.eng: He approached the king and said,

dn17:1.16.4.pli: ‘appossukko tvaṃ, deva, hohi, ahaṃ te dhanena dhanakaraṇīyaṃ karissāmī’ti.
dn17:1.16.4.eng: ‘Relax, sire. I will take care of the treasury.’

dn17:1.16.5.pli: Bhūtapubbaṃ, ānanda, rājā mahāsudassano tameva gahapatiratanaṃ vīmaṃsamāno nāvaṃ abhiruhitvā majjhe gaṅgāya nadiyā sotaṃ ogāhitvā gahapatiratanaṃ etadavoca:
dn17:1.16.5.eng: Once it so happened that the wheel-turning monarch, testing that same householder-treasure, boarded a boat and sailed to the middle of the Ganges river. Then he said to the householder-treasure,

dn17:1.16.6.eng: ‘Householder, I need gold, both coined and uncoined.’

dn17:1.16.7.pli: ‘Tena hi, mahārāja, ekaṃ tīraṃ nāvā upetū’ti.
dn17:1.16.7.eng: ‘Well then, great king, draw the boat up to one shore.’

dn17:1.16.8.eng: ‘It’s right here, householder, that I need gold, both coined and uncoined.’

dn17:1.16.9.pli: Atha kho taṃ, ānanda, gahapatiratanaṃ ubhohi hatthehi udakaṃ omasitvā pūraṃ hiraññasuvaṇṇassa kumbhiṃ uddharitvā rājānaṃ mahāsudassanaṃ etadavoca:
dn17:1.16.9.eng: Then that householder-treasure, immersing both hands in the water, pulled up a pot full of gold, both coined and uncoined, and said to the king,

dn17:1.16.10.eng: ‘Is this sufficient, great king? Has enough been done, great king, enough offered?’

dn17:1.16.12.eng: ‘That is sufficient, householder. Enough has been done, enough offered.’

dn17:1.16.13.pli: Rañño, ānanda, mahāsudassanassa evarūpaṃ gahapatiratanaṃ pāturahosi.
dn17:1.16.13.eng: Such is the householder-treasure that appeared to King Mahāsudassana.

dn17:1.18.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, ānanda, rañño mahāsudassanassa pariṇāyakaratanaṃ pāturahosi
dn17:1.18.1.eng: Next, the commander-treasure appeared to King Mahāsudassana.

dn17:1.18.2.pli: paṇḍito viyatto medhāvī paṭibalo rājānaṃ mahāsudassanaṃ upayāpetabbaṃ upayāpetuṃ, apayāpetabbaṃ apayāpetuṃ, ṭhapetabbaṃ ṭhapetuṃ.
dn17:1.18.2.eng: He is astute, competent, intelligent, and capable regarding who should be ushered in to the king’s presence, who should be ushered out, and who should be kept by his side.
dn17:1.18.2.comm: The “commander” (pariṇāyaka) is mostly found in Buddhist texts of this context, and is not a regular term of governance. This passage shows that he was responsible for management of the realm, while below he appears as commander of the army (DN 17:2.8.2). Elsewhere he is said to excel in strategy (AN 5.134:2.5).

dn17:1.18.3.eng: He approached the king and said,

dn17:1.18.5.pli: Rañño, ānanda, mahāsudassanassa evarūpaṃ pariṇāyakaratanaṃ pāturahosi.
dn17:1.18.5.eng: Such is the commander-treasure that appeared to King Mahāsudassana.

dn17:1.18.6.pli: Rājā, ānanda, mahāsudassano imehi sattahi ratanehi samannāgato ahosi.
dn17:1.18.6.eng: These are the seven treasures possessed by King Mahāsudassana.

dn17:1.18.8.pli: Rājā, ānanda, mahāsudassano catūhi iddhīhi samannāgato ahosi.

dn17:1.18.9.eng: And what are the four blessings?

dn17:1.18.10.pli: Idhānanda, rājā mahāsudassano abhirūpo ahosi dassanīyo pāsādiko paramāya vaṇṇapokkharatāya samannāgato ativiya aññehi manussehi.
dn17:1.18.10.eng: He was attractive, good-looking, lovely, of surpassing beauty, more so than other humans.

dn17:1.18.11.pli: Rājā, ānanda, mahāsudassano imāya paṭhamāya iddhiyā samannāgato ahosi.

dn17:1.19.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, ānanda, rājā mahāsudassano dīghāyuko ahosi ciraṭṭhitiko ativiya aññehi manussehi.
dn17:1.19.1.eng: Furthermore, he was long-lived, more so than other humans.

dn17:1.19.2.pli: Rājā, ānanda, mahāsudassano imāya dutiyāya iddhiyā samannāgato ahosi.

dn17:1.20.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, ānanda, rājā mahāsudassano appābādho ahosi appātaṅko samavepākiniyā gahaṇiyā samannāgato nātisītāya nāccuṇhāya ativiya aññehi manussehi.
dn17:1.20.1.eng: Furthermore, he was rarely ill or unwell, and his stomach digested well, being neither too hot nor too cold, more so than other humans.

dn17:1.20.2.pli: Rājā, ānanda, mahāsudassano imāya tatiyāya iddhiyā samannāgato ahosi.

dn17:1.21.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, ānanda, rājā mahāsudassano brāhmaṇagahapatikānaṃ piyo ahosi manāpo.
dn17:1.21.1.eng: Furthermore, he was as dear and beloved to the brahmins and householders

dn17:1.21.2.pli: Seyyathāpi, ānanda, pitā puttānaṃ piyo hoti manāpo;
dn17:1.21.2.eng: as a father is to his children.

dn17:1.21.3.pli: evameva kho, ānanda, rājā mahāsudassano brāhmaṇagahapatikānaṃ piyo ahosi manāpo.

dn17:1.21.4.pli: Raññopi, ānanda, mahāsudassanassa brāhmaṇagahapatikā piyā ahesuṃ manāpā.
dn17:1.21.4.eng: And the brahmins and householders were as dear to the king

dn17:1.21.5.pli: Seyyathāpi, ānanda, pitu puttā piyā honti manāpā;
dn17:1.21.5.eng: as children are to their father.

dn17:1.21.6.pli: evameva kho, ānanda, raññopi mahāsudassanassa brāhmaṇagahapatikā piyā ahesuṃ manāpā.

dn17:1.21.7.pli: Bhūtapubbaṃ, ānanda, rājā mahāsudassano caturaṅginiyā senāya uyyānabhūmiṃ niyyāsi.
dn17:1.21.7.eng: Once it so happened that King Mahāsudassana went with his army of four divisions to visit a park.

dn17:1.21.8.pli: Atha kho, ānanda, brāhmaṇagahapatikā rājānaṃ mahāsudassanaṃ upasaṅkamitvā evamāhaṃsu:
dn17:1.21.8.eng: Then the brahmins and householders went up to him and said,

dn17:1.21.9.pli: ‘ataramāno, deva, yāhi, yathā taṃ mayaṃ cirataraṃ passeyyāmā’ti.
dn17:1.21.9.eng: ‘Slow down, Your Majesty, so we may see you longer!’

dn17:1.21.10.eng: And the king addressed his charioteer,

dn17:1.21.11.pli: ‘ataramāno, sārathi, rathaṃ pesehi, yathā ahaṃ brāhmaṇagahapatike cirataraṃ passeyyan’ti.
dn17:1.21.11.eng: ‘Drive slowly, charioteer, so I can see the brahmins and householders longer!’

dn17:1.21.12.pli: Rājā, ānanda, mahāsudassano imāya catutthiyā iddhiyā samannāgato ahosi.

dn17:1.21.13.pli: Rājā, ānanda, mahāsudassano imāhi catūhi iddhīhi samannāgato ahosi.
dn17:1.21.13.eng: These are the four blessings possessed by King Mahāsudassana.

dn17:1.22.0.eng: 4. Lotus Ponds in the Palace of Principle

dn17:1.22.1.pli: Atha kho, ānanda, rañño mahāsudassanassa etadahosi:

dn17:1.22.2.pli: ‘yannūnāhaṃ imāsu tālantarikāsu dhanusate dhanusate pokkharaṇiyo māpeyyan’ti.
dn17:1.22.2.eng: ‘Why don’t I have lotus ponds built between the palms, at intervals of a hundred bow lengths?’

dn17:1.22.3.pli: Māpesi kho, ānanda, rājā mahāsudassano tāsu tālantarikāsu dhanusate dhanusate pokkharaṇiyo.

dn17:1.22.4.pli: Tā kho panānanda, pokkharaṇiyo catunnaṃ vaṇṇānaṃ iṭṭhakāhi citā ahesuṃ—
dn17:1.22.4.eng: The lotus ponds were lined with tiles of four colors,

dn17:1.22.5.pli: ekā iṭṭhakā sovaṇṇamayā, ekā rūpiyamayā, ekā veḷuriyamayā, ekā phalikamayā.
dn17:1.22.5.eng: made of gold, silver, beryl, and crystal.

dn17:1.22.6.pli: Tāsu kho panānanda, pokkharaṇīsu cattāri cattāri sopānāni ahesuṃ catunnaṃ vaṇṇānaṃ,
dn17:1.22.6.eng: And four flights of stairs of four colors descended into each lotus pond,

dn17:1.22.7.pli: ekaṃ sopānaṃ sovaṇṇamayaṃ ekaṃ rūpiyamayaṃ ekaṃ veḷuriyamayaṃ ekaṃ phalikamayaṃ.
dn17:1.22.7.eng: made of gold, silver, beryl, and crystal.

dn17:1.22.8.pli: Sovaṇṇamayassa sopānassa sovaṇṇamayā thambhā ahesuṃ, rūpiyamayā sūciyo ca uṇhīsañca.
dn17:1.22.8.eng: The golden stairs had posts of gold, and banisters and finials of silver.

dn17:1.22.9.pli: Rūpiyamayassa sopānassa rūpiyamayā thambhā ahesuṃ, sovaṇṇamayā sūciyo ca uṇhīsañca.
dn17:1.22.9.eng: The silver stairs had posts of silver, and banisters and finials of gold.

dn17:1.22.10.pli: Veḷuriyamayassa sopānassa veḷuriyamayā thambhā ahesuṃ, phalikamayā sūciyo ca uṇhīsañca.
dn17:1.22.10.eng: The beryl stairs had posts of beryl, and banisters and finials of crystal.

dn17:1.22.11.pli: Phalikamayassa sopānassa phalikamayā thambhā ahesuṃ, veḷuriyamayā sūciyo ca uṇhīsañca.
dn17:1.22.11.eng: The crystal stairs had posts of crystal, and banisters and finials of beryl.

dn17:1.22.12.pli: Tā kho panānanda, pokkharaṇiyo dvīhi vedikāhi parikkhittā ahesuṃ ekā vedikā sovaṇṇamayā, ekā rūpiyamayā.
dn17:1.22.12.eng: Those lotus ponds were surrounded by two balustrades, made of gold and silver.

dn17:1.22.13.pli: Sovaṇṇamayāya vedikāya sovaṇṇamayā thambhā ahesuṃ, rūpiyamayā sūciyo ca uṇhīsañca.
dn17:1.22.13.eng: The golden balustrades had posts of gold, and banisters and finials of silver.

dn17:1.22.14.pli: Rūpiyamayāya vedikāya rūpiyamayā thambhā ahesuṃ, sovaṇṇamayā sūciyo ca uṇhīsañca.
dn17:1.22.14.eng: The silver balustrades had posts of silver, and banisters and finials of gold.

dn17:1.23.1.pli: Atha kho, ānanda, rañño mahāsudassanassa etadahosi:

dn17:1.23.2.pli: ‘yannūnāhaṃ imāsu pokkharaṇīsu evarūpaṃ mālaṃ ropāpeyyaṃ uppalaṃ padumaṃ kumudaṃ puṇḍarīkaṃ sabbotukaṃ sabbajanassa anāvaṭan’ti.
dn17:1.23.2.eng: ‘Why don’t I plant flowers in the lotus ponds such as blue water lilies, and lotuses of pink, yellow, and white, blooming all year round, and accessible to the public?’

dn17:1.23.3.pli: Ropāpesi kho, ānanda, rājā mahāsudassano tāsu pokkharaṇīsu evarūpaṃ mālaṃ uppalaṃ padumaṃ kumudaṃ puṇḍarīkaṃ sabbotukaṃ sabbajanassa anāvaṭaṃ.

dn17:1.23.4.pli: Atha kho, ānanda, rañño mahāsudassanassa etadahosi:

dn17:1.23.5.pli: ‘yannūnāhaṃ imāsaṃ pokkharaṇīnaṃ tīre nhāpake purise ṭhapeyyaṃ, ye āgatāgataṃ janaṃ nhāpessantī’ti.
dn17:1.23.5.eng: ‘Why don’t I appoint bath attendants to help bathe the people who come to bathe in the lotus ponds?’

dn17:1.23.6.pli: Ṭhapesi kho, ānanda, rājā mahāsudassano tāsaṃ pokkharaṇīnaṃ tīre nhāpake purise, ye āgatāgataṃ janaṃ nhāpesuṃ.

dn17:1.23.7.pli: Atha kho, ānanda, rañño mahāsudassanassa etadahosi:

dn17:1.23.8.pli: ‘yannūnāhaṃ imāsaṃ pokkharaṇīnaṃ tīre evarūpaṃ dānaṃ paṭṭhapeyyaṃ—
dn17:1.23.8.eng: ‘Why don’t I set up charities on the banks of the lotus ponds,

dn17:1.23.9.pli: annaṃ annaṭṭhikassa, pānaṃ pānaṭṭhikassa, vatthaṃ vatthaṭṭhikassa, yānaṃ yānaṭṭhikassa, sayanaṃ sayanaṭṭhikassa, itthiṃ itthiṭṭhikassa, hiraññaṃ hiraññaṭṭhikassa, suvaṇṇaṃ suvaṇṇaṭṭhikassā’ti.
dn17:1.23.9.eng: so that those in need of food, drink, clothes, vehicles, beds, women, coined gold, or uncoined gold can get what they need?’
dn17:1.23.9.comm: The jarring inclusion of “women” (itthī) in this list probably refers to state-sponsored prostitution.

dn17:1.23.10.pli: Paṭṭhapesi kho, ānanda, rājā mahāsudassano tāsaṃ pokkharaṇīnaṃ tīre evarūpaṃ dānaṃ—

dn17:1.23.11.pli: annaṃ annaṭṭhikassa, pānaṃ pānaṭṭhikassa, vatthaṃ vatthaṭṭhikassa, yānaṃ yānaṭṭhikassa, sayanaṃ sayanaṭṭhikassa, itthiṃ itthiṭṭhikassa, hiraññaṃ hiraññaṭṭhikassa, suvaṇṇaṃ suvaṇṇaṭṭhikassa.

dn17:1.24.1.pli: Atha kho, ānanda, brāhmaṇagahapatikā pahūtaṃ sāpateyyaṃ ādāya rājānaṃ mahāsudassanaṃ upasaṅkamitvā evamāhaṃsu:
dn17:1.24.1.eng: Then the brahmins and householders came to the king bringing abundant wealth and said,

dn17:1.24.2.pli: ‘idaṃ, deva, pahūtaṃ sāpateyyaṃ devaññeva uddissa ābhataṃ, taṃ devo paṭiggaṇhatū’ti.
dn17:1.24.2.eng: ‘Sire, this abundant wealth is specially for you alone; may Your Highness accept it!’

dn17:1.24.3.pli: ‘Alaṃ, bho, mamapidaṃ pahūtaṃ sāpateyyaṃ dhammikena balinā abhisaṅkhataṃ, tañca vo hotu, ito ca bhiyyo harathā’ti.
dn17:1.24.3.eng: ‘There’s enough raised for me through regular taxes. Let this be for you; and here, take even more!’

dn17:1.24.4.pli: Te raññā paṭikkhittā ekamantaṃ apakkamma evaṃ samacintesuṃ:
dn17:1.24.4.eng: When the king turned them down, they withdrew to one side to think up a plan,

dn17:1.24.5.pli: ‘na kho etaṃ amhākaṃ patirūpaṃ, yaṃ mayaṃ imāni sāpateyyāni punadeva sakāni gharāni paṭihareyyāma.
dn17:1.24.5.eng: ‘It wouldn’t be proper for us to take this abundant wealth back to our own homes.

dn17:1.24.6.pli: Yannūna mayaṃ rañño mahāsudassanassa nivesanaṃ māpeyyāmā’ti.
dn17:1.24.6.eng: Why don’t we build a home for King Mahāsudassana?’

dn17:1.24.7.eng: They went up to the king and said,

dn17:1.24.8.eng: ‘We shall have a home built for you, sire!’

dn17:1.24.9.pli: Adhivāsesi kho, ānanda, rājā mahāsudassano tuṇhībhāvena.

dn17:1.25.1.pli: Atha kho, ānanda, sakko devānamindo rañño mahāsudassanassa cetasā cetoparivitakkamaññāya vissakammaṃ devaputtaṃ āmantesi:
dn17:1.25.1.eng: And then Sakka, lord of gods, knowing the king’s train of thought, addressed the godling Vissakamma,

dn17:1.25.2.pli: ‘ehi tvaṃ, samma vissakamma, rañño mahāsudassanassa nivesanaṃ māpehi dhammaṃ nāma pāsādan’ti.
dn17:1.25.2.eng: ‘Come, dear Vissakamma, build a palace named Principle as a home for King Mahāsudassana.’
dn17:1.25.2.comm: The palace is named “Principle” (dhamma) in recognition of the king being subject to a higher law. Normally I translate pāsāda as “stilt longhouse” but here something grander is meant.

dn17:1.25.3.pli: ‘Evaṃ, bhaddantavā’ti kho, ānanda, vissakammo devaputto sakkassa devānamindassa paṭissutvā seyyathāpi nāma balavā puriso samiñjitaṃ vā bāhaṃ pasāreyya pasāritaṃ vā bāhaṃ samiñjeyya; evameva—devesu tāvatiṃsesu antarahito rañño mahāsudassanassa purato pāturahosi.
dn17:1.25.3.eng: ‘Yes, lord,’ replied Vissakamma. Then, as easily as a strong person would extend or contract their arm, he vanished from the gods of the thirty-three and appeared in front of King Mahāsudassana.

dn17:1.25.4.pli: Atha kho, ānanda, vissakammo devaputto rājānaṃ mahāsudassanaṃ etadavoca:

dn17:1.25.5.pli: ‘nivesanaṃ te, deva, māpessāmi dhammaṃ nāma pāsādan’ti.
dn17:1.25.5.eng: ‘I shall build a palace named Principle as a home for you, sire.’

dn17:1.25.6.pli: Adhivāsesi kho, ānanda, rājā mahāsudassano tuṇhībhāvena.

dn17:1.25.7.pli: Māpesi kho, ānanda, vissakammo devaputto rañño mahāsudassanassa nivesanaṃ dhammaṃ nāma pāsādaṃ.
dn17:1.25.7.eng: And so that’s what Vissakamma did.

dn17:1.25.8.pli: Dhammo, ānanda, pāsādo puratthimena pacchimena ca yojanaṃ āyāmena ahosi. Uttarena dakkhiṇena ca aḍḍhayojanaṃ vitthārena.
dn17:1.25.8.eng: The Palace of Principle stretched for a league from east to west, and half a league from north to south.

dn17:1.25.9.pli: Dhammassa, ānanda, pāsādassa tiporisaṃ uccatarena vatthu citaṃ ahosi catunnaṃ vaṇṇānaṃ iṭṭhakāhi—
dn17:1.25.9.eng: It was lined with tiles of four colors, three fathoms high,

dn17:1.25.10.pli: ekā iṭṭhakā sovaṇṇamayā, ekā rūpiyamayā, ekā veḷuriyamayā, ekā phalikamayā.
dn17:1.25.10.eng: made of gold, silver, beryl, and crystal.

dn17:1.26.1.pli: Dhammassa, ānanda, pāsādassa caturāsītithambhasahassāni ahesuṃ catunnaṃ vaṇṇānaṃ—
dn17:1.26.1.eng: It had 84,000 pillars of four colors,

dn17:1.26.2.pli: eko thambho sovaṇṇamayo, eko rūpiyamayo, eko veḷuriyamayo, eko phalikamayo.
dn17:1.26.2.eng: made of gold, silver, beryl, and crystal.

dn17:1.26.3.pli: Dhammo, ānanda, pāsādo catunnaṃ vaṇṇānaṃ phalakehi santhato ahosi—
dn17:1.26.3.eng: It was covered with panels of four colors,

dn17:1.26.4.pli: ekaṃ phalakaṃ sovaṇṇamayaṃ, ekaṃ rūpiyamayaṃ, ekaṃ veḷuriyamayaṃ, ekaṃ phalikamayaṃ.
dn17:1.26.4.eng: made of gold, silver, beryl, and crystal.

dn17:1.26.5.pli: Dhammassa, ānanda, pāsādassa catuvīsati sopānāni ahesuṃ catunnaṃ vaṇṇānaṃ—
dn17:1.26.5.eng: It had twenty-four staircases of four colors,

dn17:1.26.6.pli: ekaṃ sopānaṃ sovaṇṇamayaṃ, ekaṃ rūpiyamayaṃ, ekaṃ veḷuriyamayaṃ, ekaṃ phalikamayaṃ.
dn17:1.26.6.eng: made of gold, silver, beryl, and crystal.

dn17:1.26.7.pli: Sovaṇṇamayassa sopānassa sovaṇṇamayā thambhā ahesuṃ rūpiyamayā sūciyo ca uṇhīsañca.
dn17:1.26.7.eng: The golden stairs had posts of gold, and banisters and finials of silver.

dn17:1.26.8.pli: Rūpiyamayassa sopānassa rūpiyamayā thambhā ahesuṃ sovaṇṇamayā sūciyo ca uṇhīsañca.
dn17:1.26.8.eng: The silver stairs had posts of silver, and banisters and finials of gold.

dn17:1.26.9.pli: Veḷuriyamayassa sopānassa veḷuriyamayā thambhā ahesuṃ phalikamayā sūciyo ca uṇhīsañca.
dn17:1.26.9.eng: The beryl stairs had posts of beryl, and banisters and finials of crystal.

dn17:1.26.10.pli: Phalikamayassa sopānassa phalikamayā thambhā ahesuṃ veḷuriyamayā sūciyo ca uṇhīsañca.
dn17:1.26.10.eng: The crystal stairs had posts of crystal, and banisters and finials of beryl.

dn17:1.26.11.pli: Dhamme, ānanda, pāsāde caturāsītikūṭāgārasahassāni ahesuṃ catunnaṃ vaṇṇānaṃ—
dn17:1.26.11.eng: It had 84,000 chambers of four colors,
dn17:1.26.11.comm: For kūṭāgāra as “chamber” see MN 37:8.10.

dn17:1.26.12.pli: ekaṃ kūṭāgāraṃ sovaṇṇamayaṃ, ekaṃ rūpiyamayaṃ, ekaṃ veḷuriyamayaṃ, ekaṃ phalikamayaṃ.
dn17:1.26.12.eng: made of gold, silver, beryl, and crystal.

dn17:1.26.13.pli: Sovaṇṇamaye kūṭāgāre rūpiyamayo pallaṅko paññatto ahosi, rūpiyamaye kūṭāgāre sovaṇṇamayo pallaṅko paññatto ahosi, veḷuriyamaye kūṭāgāre dantamayo pallaṅko paññatto ahosi, phalikamaye kūṭāgāre sāramayo pallaṅko paññatto ahosi.
dn17:1.26.13.eng: In each chamber a couch was spread: in the golden chamber a couch of silver; in the silver chamber a couch of gold; in the beryl chamber a couch of ivory; in the crystal chamber a couch of hardwood.

dn17:1.26.14.pli: Sovaṇṇamayassa kūṭāgārassa dvāre rūpiyamayo tālo ṭhito ahosi, tassa rūpiyamayo khandho sovaṇṇamayāni pattāni ca phalāni ca.
dn17:1.26.14.eng: At the door of the golden chamber stood a palm tree of silver, with trunk of silver, and leaves and fruits of gold.

dn17:1.26.15.pli: Rūpiyamayassa kūṭāgārassa dvāre sovaṇṇamayo tālo ṭhito ahosi, tassa sovaṇṇamayo khandho, rūpiyamayāni pattāni ca phalāni ca.
dn17:1.26.15.eng: At the door of the silver chamber stood a palm tree of gold, with trunk of gold, and leaves and fruits of silver.

dn17:1.26.16.pli: Veḷuriyamayassa kūṭāgārassa dvāre phalikamayo tālo ṭhito ahosi, tassa phalikamayo khandho, veḷuriyamayāni pattāni ca phalāni ca.
dn17:1.26.16.eng: At the door of the beryl chamber stood a palm tree of crystal, with trunk of crystal, and leaves and fruits of beryl.

dn17:1.26.17.pli: Phalikamayassa kūṭāgārassa dvāre veḷuriyamayo tālo ṭhito ahosi, tassa veḷuriyamayo khandho, phalikamayāni pattāni ca phalāni ca.
dn17:1.26.17.eng: At the door of the crystal chamber stood a palm tree of beryl, with trunk of beryl, and leaves and fruits of crystal.

dn17:1.27.1.pli: Atha kho, ānanda, rañño mahāsudassanassa etadahosi:

dn17:1.27.2.pli: ‘yannūnāhaṃ mahāviyūhassa kūṭāgārassa dvāre sabbasovaṇṇamayaṃ tālavanaṃ māpeyyaṃ, yattha divāvihāraṃ nisīdissāmī’ti.
dn17:1.27.2.eng: ‘Why don’t I build a grove of golden palm trees at the door to the Chamber of the Grand Tower, where I can sit for the day?’

dn17:1.27.3.pli: Māpesi kho, ānanda, rājā mahāsudassano mahāviyūhassa kūṭāgārassa dvāre sabbasovaṇṇamayaṃ tālavanaṃ, yattha divāvihāraṃ nisīdi.

dn17:1.28.1.pli: Dhammo, ānanda, pāsādo dvīhi vedikāhi parikkhitto ahosi, ekā vedikā sovaṇṇamayā, ekā rūpiyamayā.
dn17:1.28.1.eng: The Palace of Principle was surrounded by two balustrades, made of gold and silver.

dn17:1.28.2.pli: Sovaṇṇamayāya vedikāya sovaṇṇamayā thambhā ahesuṃ, rūpiyamayā sūciyo ca uṇhīsañca.
dn17:1.28.2.eng: The golden balustrades had posts of gold, and banisters and finials of silver.

dn17:1.28.3.pli: Rūpiyamayāya vedikāya rūpiyamayā thambhā ahesuṃ, sovaṇṇamayā sūciyo ca uṇhīsañca.
dn17:1.28.3.eng: The silver balustrades had posts of silver, and banisters and finials of gold.

dn17:1.29.1.pli: Dhammo, ānanda, pāsādo dvīhi kiṅkiṇikajālehi parikkhitto ahosi—
dn17:1.29.1.eng: The Palace of Principle was surrounded by two nets of bells,

dn17:1.29.3.pli: Sovaṇṇamayassa jālassa rūpiyamayā kiṅkiṇikā ahesuṃ, rūpiyamayassa jālassa sovaṇṇamayā kiṅkiṇikā ahesuṃ.
dn17:1.29.3.eng: The golden net had bells of silver, and the silver net had bells of gold.

dn17:1.29.4.pli: Tesaṃ kho panānanda, kiṅkiṇikajālānaṃ vāteritānaṃ saddo ahosi vaggu ca rajanīyo ca khamanīyo ca madanīyo ca.
dn17:1.29.4.eng: When those nets of bells were blown by the wind they sounded graceful, tantalizing, sensuous, lovely, and intoxicating,

dn17:1.29.5.pli: Seyyathāpi, ānanda, pañcaṅgikassa tūriyassa suvinītassa suppaṭitāḷitassa sukusalehi samannāhatassa saddo hoti, vaggu ca rajanīyo ca khamanīyo ca madanīyo ca;
dn17:1.29.5.eng: like a quintet made up of skilled musicians who had practiced well and kept excellent rhythm.

dn17:1.29.6.pli: evameva kho, ānanda, tesaṃ kiṅkiṇikajālānaṃ vāteritānaṃ saddo ahosi vaggu ca rajanīyo ca khamanīyo ca madanīyo ca.

dn17:1.29.7.pli: Ye kho panānanda, tena samayena kusāvatiyā rājadhāniyā dhuttā ahesuṃ soṇḍā pipāsā, te tesaṃ kiṅkiṇikajālānaṃ vāteritānaṃ saddena paricāresuṃ.
dn17:1.29.7.eng: And any addicts, carousers, or drunkards in Kusāvatī at that time were entertained by that sound.

dn17:1.29.8.pli: Niṭṭhito kho panānanda, dhammo pāsādo duddikkho ahosi musati cakkhūni.
dn17:1.29.8.eng: When it was finished, the palace was hard to look at, dazzling to the eyes.

dn17:1.29.9.pli: Seyyathāpi, ānanda, vassānaṃ pacchime māse saradasamaye viddhe vigatavalāhake deve ādicco nabhaṃ abbhussakkamāno duddikkho hoti musati cakkhūni;
dn17:1.29.9.eng: It was like how in the last month of the rainy season, in autumn, when the heavens are sunny and cloudless, as the sun is rising to the firmament, it is hard to look at, dazzling to the eyes.

dn17:1.29.10.pli: evameva kho, ānanda, dhammo pāsādo duddikkho ahosi musati cakkhūni.

dn17:1.30.1.pli: Atha kho, ānanda, rañño mahāsudassanassa etadahosi:

dn17:1.30.2.pli: ‘yannūnāhaṃ dhammassa pāsādassa purato dhammaṃ nāma pokkharaṇiṃ māpeyyan’ti.
dn17:1.30.2.eng: ‘Why don’t I build a lotus pond named Principle in front of the palace?’

dn17:1.30.3.pli: Māpesi kho, ānanda, rājā mahāsudassano dhammassa pāsādassa purato dhammaṃ nāma pokkharaṇiṃ.

dn17:1.30.4.pli: Dhammā, ānanda, pokkharaṇī puratthimena pacchimena ca yojanaṃ āyāmena ahosi, uttarena dakkhiṇena ca aḍḍhayojanaṃ vitthārena.
dn17:1.30.4.eng: The Lotus Pond of Principle stretched for a league from east to west, and half a league from north to south.

dn17:1.30.5.pli: Dhammā, ānanda, pokkharaṇī catunnaṃ vaṇṇānaṃ iṭṭhakāhi citā ahosi—
dn17:1.30.5.eng: It was lined with tiles of four colors,

dn17:1.30.6.pli: ekā iṭṭhakā sovaṇṇamayā, ekā rūpiyamayā, ekā veḷuriyamayā, ekā phalikamayā.
dn17:1.30.6.eng: made of gold, silver, beryl, and crystal.

dn17:1.31.1.pli: Dhammāya, ānanda, pokkharaṇiyā catuvīsati sopānāni ahesuṃ catunnaṃ vaṇṇānaṃ—
dn17:1.31.1.eng: It had twenty-four staircases of four colors,

dn17:1.31.2.pli: ekaṃ sopānaṃ sovaṇṇamayaṃ, ekaṃ rūpiyamayaṃ, ekaṃ veḷuriyamayaṃ, ekaṃ phalikamayaṃ.
dn17:1.31.2.eng: made of gold, silver, beryl, and crystal.

dn17:1.31.3.pli: Sovaṇṇamayassa sopānassa sovaṇṇamayā thambhā ahesuṃ rūpiyamayā sūciyo ca uṇhīsañca.
dn17:1.31.3.eng: The golden stairs had posts of gold, and banisters and finials of silver.

dn17:1.31.4.pli: Rūpiyamayassa sopānassa rūpiyamayā thambhā ahesuṃ sovaṇṇamayā sūciyo ca uṇhīsañca.
dn17:1.31.4.eng: The silver stairs had posts of silver, and banisters and finials of gold.

dn17:1.31.5.pli: Veḷuriyamayassa sopānassa veḷuriyamayā thambhā ahesuṃ phalikamayā sūciyo ca uṇhīsañca.
dn17:1.31.5.eng: The beryl stairs had posts of beryl, and banisters and finials of crystal.

dn17:1.31.6.pli: Phalikamayassa sopānassa phalikamayā thambhā ahesuṃ veḷuriyamayā sūciyo ca uṇhīsañca.
dn17:1.31.6.eng: The crystal stairs had posts of crystal, and banisters and finials of beryl.

dn17:1.31.7.pli: Dhammā, ānanda, pokkharaṇī dvīhi vedikāhi parikkhittā ahosi—ekā vedikā sovaṇṇamayā, ekā rūpiyamayā.
dn17:1.31.7.eng: It was surrounded by two balustrades, made of gold and silver.

dn17:1.31.8.pli: Sovaṇṇamayāya vedikāya sovaṇṇamayā thambhā ahesuṃ rūpiyamayā sūciyo ca uṇhīsañca.
dn17:1.31.8.eng: The golden balustrades had posts of gold, and banisters and finials of silver.

dn17:1.31.9.pli: Rūpiyamayāya vedikāya rūpiyamayā thambhā ahesuṃ sovaṇṇamayā sūciyo ca uṇhīsañca.
dn17:1.31.9.eng: The silver balustrades had posts of silver, and banisters and finials of gold.

dn17:1.32.1.pli: Dhammā, ānanda, pokkharaṇī sattahi tālapantīhi parikkhittā ahosi—
dn17:1.32.1.eng: It was surrounded by seven rows of palm trees,

dn17:1.32.2.pli: ekā tālapanti sovaṇṇamayā, ekā rūpiyamayā, ekā veḷuriyamayā, ekā phalikamayā, ekā lohitaṅkamayā, ekā masāragallamayā, ekā sabbaratanamayā.
dn17:1.32.2.eng: made of gold, silver, beryl, crystal, ruby, emerald, and all precious things.

dn17:1.32.3.pli: Sovaṇṇamayassa tālassa sovaṇṇamayo khandho ahosi rūpiyamayāni pattāni ca phalāni ca.
dn17:1.32.3.eng: The golden palms had trunks of gold, and leaves and fruits of silver.

dn17:1.32.4.pli: Rūpiyamayassa tālassa rūpiyamayo khandho ahosi sovaṇṇamayāni pattāni ca phalāni ca.
dn17:1.32.4.eng: The silver palms had trunks of silver, and leaves and fruits of gold.

dn17:1.32.5.pli: Veḷuriyamayassa tālassa veḷuriyamayo khandho ahosi phalikamayāni pattāni ca phalāni ca.
dn17:1.32.5.eng: The beryl palms had trunks of beryl, and leaves and fruits of crystal.

dn17:1.32.6.pli: Phalikamayassa tālassa phalikamayo khandho ahosi veḷuriyamayāni pattāni ca phalāni ca.
dn17:1.32.6.eng: The crystal palms had trunks of crystal, and leaves and fruits of beryl.

dn17:1.32.7.pli: Lohitaṅkamayassa tālassa lohitaṅkamayo khandho ahosi masāragallamayāni pattāni ca phalāni ca.
dn17:1.32.7.eng: The ruby palms had trunks of ruby, and leaves and fruits of emerald.

dn17:1.32.8.pli: Masāragallamayassa tālassa masāragallamayo khandho ahosi lohitaṅkamayāni pattāni ca phalāni ca.
dn17:1.32.8.eng: The emerald palms had trunks of emerald, and leaves and fruits of ruby.

dn17:1.32.9.pli: Sabbaratanamayassa tālassa sabbaratanamayo khandho ahosi, sabbaratanamayāni pattāni ca phalāni ca.
dn17:1.32.9.eng: The palms of all precious things had trunks of all precious things, and leaves and fruits of all precious things.

dn17:1.32.10.pli: Tāsaṃ kho panānanda, tālapantīnaṃ vāteritānaṃ saddo ahosi, vaggu ca rajanīyo ca khamanīyo ca madanīyo ca.
dn17:1.32.10.eng: When those rows of palm trees were blown by the wind they sounded graceful, tantalizing, sensuous, lovely, and intoxicating,

dn17:1.32.11.pli: Seyyathāpi, ānanda, pañcaṅgikassa tūriyassa suvinītassa suppaṭitāḷitassa sukusalehi samannāhatassa saddo hoti vaggu ca rajanīyo ca khamanīyo ca madanīyo ca;
dn17:1.32.11.eng: like a quintet made up of skilled musicians who had practiced well and kept excellent rhythm.

dn17:1.32.12.pli: evameva kho, ānanda, tāsaṃ tālapantīnaṃ vāteritānaṃ saddo ahosi vaggu ca rajanīyo ca khamanīyo ca madanīyo ca.

dn17:1.32.13.pli: Ye kho panānanda, tena samayena kusāvatiyā rājadhāniyā dhuttā ahesuṃ soṇḍā pipāsā, te tāsaṃ tālapantīnaṃ vāteritānaṃ saddena paricāresuṃ.
dn17:1.32.13.eng: And any addicts, carousers, or drunkards in Kusāvatī at that time were entertained by that sound.

dn17:1.33.1.pli: Niṭṭhite kho panānanda, dhamme pāsāde niṭṭhitāya dhammāya ca pokkharaṇiyā rājā mahāsudassano ‘ye tena samayena samaṇesu vā samaṇasammatā brāhmaṇesu vā brāhmaṇasammatā’, te sabbakāmehi santappetvā dhammaṃ pāsādaṃ abhiruhi.
dn17:1.33.1.eng: When the palace and its lotus pond were finished, King Mahāsudassana served those who were deemed true ascetics and brahmins with all they desired. Then he ascended the Palace of Principle.

dn17:2.1.1.pli: Atha kho, ānanda, rañño mahāsudassanassa etadahosi:

dn17:2.1.2.pli: ‘kissa nu kho me idaṃ kammassa phalaṃ kissa kammassa vipāko, yenāhaṃ etarahi evaṃmahiddhiko evaṃmahānubhāvo’ti?
dn17:2.1.2.eng: ‘Of what deed of mine is this the fruit and result, that I am now so mighty and powerful?’

dn17:2.1.3.pli: Atha kho, ānanda, rañño mahāsudassanassa etadahosi:

dn17:2.1.4.pli: ‘tiṇṇaṃ kho me idaṃ kammānaṃ phalaṃ tiṇṇaṃ kammānaṃ vipāko, yenāhaṃ etarahi evaṃmahiddhiko evaṃmahānubhāvo, seyyathidaṃ—
dn17:2.1.4.eng: ‘It is the fruit and result of three kinds of deeds:
dn17:2.1.4.comm: Thus denying the doctrine of Pūraṇa Kassapa at DN 2:17.5. This is the recognition, at least partially, of right view.

dn17:2.2.1.pli: Atha kho, ānanda, rājā mahāsudassano yena mahāviyūhaṃ kūṭāgāraṃ tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā mahāviyūhassa kūṭāgārassa dvāre ṭhito udānaṃ udānesi:
dn17:2.2.1.eng: Then he went to the Chamber of the Grand Tower, stood at the door, and expressed this heartfelt sentiment:

dn17:2.2.2.eng: ‘Stop here, sensual, malicious, and cruel thoughts—
dn17:2.2.2.comm: These are the three factors of right thought. The king skillfully uses a transition in physical space to set up his intention to meditate.

dn17:2.2.3.pli: Ettāvatā, kāmavitakka, ettāvatā, byāpādavitakka, ettāvatā, vihiṃsāvitakkā’ti.

dn17:2.3.1.pli: Atha kho, ānanda, rājā mahāsudassano mahāviyūhaṃ kūṭāgāraṃ pavisitvā sovaṇṇamaye pallaṅke nisinno vivicceva kāmehi vivicca akusalehi dhammehi savitakkaṃ savicāraṃ vivekajaṃ pītisukhaṃ paṭhamaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja vihāsi.
dn17:2.3.1.eng: Then he entered the Chamber of the Grand Tower and sat on the golden couch. Quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, he entered and remained in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected.
dn17:2.3.1.comm: Here as in DN 1, jhāna is not a uniquely Buddhist practice.

dn17:2.3.2.pli: Vitakkavicārānaṃ vūpasamā ajjhattaṃ sampasādanaṃ cetaso ekodibhāvaṃ avitakkaṃ avicāraṃ samādhijaṃ pītisukhaṃ dutiyaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja vihāsi.
dn17:2.3.2.eng: As the placing of the mind and keeping it connected were stilled, he entered and remained in the second absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of immersion, with internal clarity and mind at one, without placing the mind and keeping it connected.

dn17:2.3.3.pli: Pītiyā ca virāgā upekkhako ca vihāsi, sato ca sampajāno sukhañca kāyena paṭisaṃvedesi, yaṃ taṃ ariyā ācikkhanti: ‘upekkhako satimā sukhavihārī’ti tatiyaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja vihāsi.
dn17:2.3.3.eng: And with the fading away of rapture, he entered and remained in the third absorption, where he meditated with equanimity, mindful and aware, personally experiencing the bliss of which the noble ones declare, ‘Equanimous and mindful, one meditates in bliss.’

dn17:2.3.4.pli: Sukhassa ca pahānā dukkhassa ca pahānā pubbeva somanassadomanassānaṃ atthaṅgamā adukkhamasukhaṃ upekkhāsatipārisuddhiṃ catutthaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja vihāsi.
dn17:2.3.4.eng: With the giving up of pleasure and pain, and the ending of former happiness and sadness, he entered and remained in the fourth absorption, without pleasure or pain, with pure equanimity and mindfulness.

dn17:2.4.1.pli: Atha kho, ānanda, rājā mahāsudassano mahāviyūhā kūṭāgārā nikkhamitvā sovaṇṇamayaṃ kūṭāgāraṃ pavisitvā rūpiyamaye pallaṅke nisinno
dn17:2.4.1.eng: Then King Mahāsudassana left the Chamber of the Grand Tower and entered the golden chamber, where he sat on the golden couch.

dn17:2.4.2.pli: mettāsahagatena cetasā ekaṃ disaṃ pharitvā vihāsi. Tathā dutiyaṃ tathā tatiyaṃ tathā catutthaṃ. Iti uddhamadho tiriyaṃ sabbadhi sabbattatāya sabbāvantaṃ lokaṃ mettāsahagatena cetasā vipulena mahaggatena appamāṇena averena abyāpajjena pharitvā vihāsi.
dn17:2.4.2.eng: He meditated spreading a heart full of love to one direction, and to the second, and to the third, and to the fourth. In the same way he spread a heart full of love above, below, across, everywhere, all around, to everyone in the world—abundant, expansive, limitless, free of enmity and ill will.

dn17:2.4.3.eng: He meditated spreading a heart full of compassion …

dn17:2.4.4.eng: He meditated spreading a heart full of rejoicing …

dn17:2.4.5.pli: upekkhāsahagatena cetasā ekaṃ disaṃ pharitvā vihāsi. Tathā dutiyaṃ tathā tatiyaṃ tathā catutthaṃ. Iti uddhamadho tiriyaṃ sabbadhi sabbattatāya sabbāvantaṃ lokaṃ upekkhāsahagatena cetasā vipulena mahaggatena appamāṇena averena abyāpajjena pharitvā vihāsi.
dn17:2.4.5.eng: He meditated spreading a heart full of equanimity to one direction, and to the second, and to the third, and to the fourth. In the same way above, below, across, everywhere, all around, he spread a heart full of equanimity to the whole world—abundant, expansive, limitless, free of enmity and ill will.

dn17:2.5.1.pli: Rañño, ānanda, mahāsudassanassa caturāsīti nagarasahassāni ahesuṃ kusāvatīrājadhānippamukhāni;
dn17:2.5.1.eng: King Mahāsudassana had 84,000 cities, with the royal capital of Kusāvatī the foremost.

dn17:2.5.2.eng: He had 84,000 palaces, with the Palace of Principle the foremost.

dn17:2.5.3.eng: He had 84,000 chambers, with the Chamber of the Grand Tower the foremost.
dn17:2.5.3.comm: “Chamber” is kūṭāgāra, literally “building with peaked roof”. Normally this means “bungalow”, but in a similar description at MN 37:8.9 we hear of a “palace” with a hundred “towers” (niyyūha), each of which has seven hundred “chambers”. Thus the kūṭāgāra must be a structure many of which can belong to a palace, namely “chamber”, while viyūha (spelled byūha at SN 22.96:3.4) must have the same meaning as niyyūha, i.e. “tower”.

dn17:2.5.4.pli: caturāsīti pallaṅkasahassāni ahesuṃ sovaṇṇamayāni rūpiyamayāni dantamayāni sāramayāni gonakatthatāni paṭikatthatāni paṭalikatthatāni kadalimigapavarapaccattharaṇāni sauttaracchadāni ubhatolohitakūpadhānāni;
dn17:2.5.4.eng: He had 84,000 couches made of gold, silver, ivory, and hardwood. They were spread with woollen covers—shag-piled, pure white, or embroidered with flowers—and spread with a fine deer hide, with a canopy above and red pillows at both ends.
dn17:2.5.4.comm: This segment breaks the expected pattern of “foremost” things.

dn17:2.5.5.pli: caturāsīti nāgasahassāni ahesuṃ sovaṇṇālaṅkārāni sovaṇṇadhajāni hemajālapaṭicchannāni uposathanāgarājappamukhāni;
dn17:2.5.5.eng: He had 84,000 bull elephants with gold adornments and banners, covered with snow gold netting, with the royal bull elephant named Sabbath foremost.

dn17:2.5.6.pli: caturāsīti assasahassāni ahesuṃ sovaṇṇālaṅkārāni sovaṇṇadhajāni hemajālapaṭicchannāni valāhakaassarājappamukhāni;
dn17:2.5.6.eng: He had 84,000 horses with gold adornments and banners, covered with snow gold netting, with the royal steed named Thundercloud foremost.

dn17:2.5.7.pli: caturāsīti rathasahassāni ahesuṃ sīhacammaparivārāni byagghacammaparivārāni dīpicammaparivārāni paṇḍukambalaparivārāni sovaṇṇālaṅkārāni sovaṇṇadhajāni hemajālapaṭicchannāni vejayantarathappamukhāni;
dn17:2.5.7.eng: He had 84,000 chariots upholstered with the hide of lions, tigers, and leopards, and cream rugs, with gold adornments and banners, covered with snow gold netting, with the chariot named Triumph foremost.
dn17:2.5.7.comm: Not the British car of the same name. The chariot is the source of victory in battle.

dn17:2.5.8.eng: He had 84,000 jewels, with the jewel-treasure foremost.

dn17:2.5.9.eng: He had 84,000 women, with Queen Subhaddā foremost.

dn17:2.5.10.eng: He had 84,000 householders, with the householder-treasure foremost.

dn17:2.5.11.eng: He had 84,000 aristocrat vassals, with the commander-treasure foremost.

dn17:2.5.12.eng: He had 84,000 milk-cows with silken halter and bronze pails.
dn17:2.5.12.comm: Read dukūlasandanāni, where dukūla is “fine cloth, silk” and sandana is “cord, tether”.

dn17:2.5.13.pli: caturāsīti vatthakoṭisahassāni ahesuṃ khomasukhumānaṃ kappāsikasukhumānaṃ koseyyasukhumānaṃ kambalasukhumānaṃ;
dn17:2.5.13.eng: He had 8,400,000,000 delicate cloths of linen, cotton, silk, and wool.

dn17:2.5.14.pli: rañño, ānanda, mahāsudassanassa caturāsīti thālipākasahassāni ahesuṃ sāyaṃ pātaṃ bhattābhihāro abhihariyittha.
dn17:2.5.14.eng: He had 84,000 servings of food, which were presented to him as offerings at daybreak and dusk.

dn17:2.6.1.pli: Tena kho panānanda, samayena rañño mahāsudassanassa caturāsīti nāgasahassāni sāyaṃ pātaṃ upaṭṭhānaṃ āgacchanti.
dn17:2.6.1.eng: Now at that time his 84,000 royal elephants came to attend on him at daybreak and dusk.

dn17:2.6.2.pli: Atha kho, ānanda, rañño mahāsudassanassa etadahosi:

dn17:2.6.3.pli: ‘imāni kho me caturāsīti nāgasahassāni sāyaṃ pātaṃ upaṭṭhānaṃ āgacchanti, yannūna vassasatassa vassasatassa accayena dvecattālīsaṃ dvecattālīsaṃ nāgasahassāni sakiṃ sakiṃ upaṭṭhānaṃ āgaccheyyun’ti.
dn17:2.6.3.eng: ‘What if instead half of the elephants took turns to attend on me at the end of each century?’
dn17:2.6.3.comm: An odd detail. Maybe the sound of the elephants disturbed his meditation?

dn17:2.6.4.pli: Atha kho, ānanda, rājā mahāsudassano pariṇāyakaratanaṃ āmantesi:
dn17:2.6.4.eng: He instructed the commander-treasure to do this, and so it was done.

dn17:2.6.5.pli: ‘imāni kho me, samma pariṇāyakaratana, caturāsīti nāgasahassāni sāyaṃ pātaṃ upaṭṭhānaṃ āgacchanti, tena hi, samma pariṇāyakaratana, vassasatassa vassasatassa accayena dvecattālīsaṃ dvecattālīsaṃ nāgasahassāni sakiṃ sakiṃ upaṭṭhānaṃ āgacchantū’ti.

dn17:2.6.6.pli: ‘Evaṃ, devā’ti kho, ānanda, pariṇāyakaratanaṃ rañño mahāsudassanassa paccassosi.

dn17:2.6.7.pli: Atha kho, ānanda, rañño mahāsudassanassa aparena samayena vassasatassa vassasatassa accayena dvecattālīsaṃ dvecattālīsaṃ nāgasahassāni sakiṃ sakiṃ upaṭṭhānaṃ āgamaṃsu.

dn17:2.7.1.pli: Atha kho, ānanda, subhaddāya deviyā bahunnaṃ vassānaṃ bahunnaṃ vassasatānaṃ bahunnaṃ vassasahassānaṃ accayena etadahosi:
dn17:2.7.1.eng: Then, after many years, many hundred years, many thousand years had passed, Queen Subhaddā thought,

dn17:2.7.2.pli: ‘ciraṃ diṭṭho kho me rājā mahāsudassano. Yannūnāhaṃ rājānaṃ mahāsudassanaṃ dassanāya upasaṅkameyyan’ti.
dn17:2.7.2.eng: ‘It is long since I have seen the king. Why don’t I go to see him?’

dn17:2.7.3.pli: Atha kho, ānanda, subhaddā devī itthāgāraṃ āmantesi:
dn17:2.7.3.eng: So the queen addressed the ladies of the harem,

dn17:2.7.4.pli: ‘etha tumhe sīsāni nhāyatha pītāni vatthāni pārupatha.
dn17:2.7.4.eng: ‘Come, bathe your heads and dress in yellow.

dn17:2.7.5.pli: Ciraṃ diṭṭho no rājā mahāsudassano, rājānaṃ mahāsudassanaṃ dassanāya upasaṅkamissāmā’ti.
dn17:2.7.5.eng: It is long since we saw the king, and we shall go to see him.’

dn17:2.7.6.pli: ‘Evaṃ, ayye’ti kho, ānanda, itthāgāraṃ subhaddāya deviyā paṭissutvā sīsāni nhāyitvā pītāni vatthāni pārupitvā yena subhaddā devī tenupasaṅkami.
dn17:2.7.6.eng: ‘Yes, ma’am,’ replied the ladies of the harem. They did as she asked and returned to the queen.

dn17:2.8.1.pli: Atha kho, ānanda, subhaddā devī pariṇāyakaratanaṃ āmantesi:
dn17:2.8.1.eng: Then the queen addressed the commander-treasure,

dn17:2.8.2.pli: ‘kappehi, samma pariṇāyakaratana, caturaṅginiṃ senaṃ, ciraṃ diṭṭho no rājā mahāsudassano, rājānaṃ mahāsudassanaṃ dassanāya upasaṅkamissāmā’ti.
dn17:2.8.2.eng: ‘Dear commander-treasure, please ready the army of four divisions. It is long since we saw the king, and we shall go to see him.’

dn17:2.8.3.pli: ‘Evaṃ, devī’ti kho, ānanda, pariṇāyakaratanaṃ subhaddāya deviyā paṭissutvā caturaṅginiṃ senaṃ kappāpetvā subhaddāya deviyā paṭivedesi:
dn17:2.8.3.eng: ‘Yes, my queen,’ he replied, and did as he was asked. He informed the queen,

dn17:2.8.4.eng: ‘My queen, the army of four divisions is ready,

dn17:2.8.6.pli: Atha kho, ānanda, subhaddā devī caturaṅginiyā senāya saddhiṃ itthāgārena yena dhammo pāsādo tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā dhammaṃ pāsādaṃ abhiruhitvā yena mahāviyūhaṃ kūṭāgāraṃ tenupasaṅkami.
dn17:2.8.6.eng: Then Queen Subhaddā together with the ladies of the harem went with the army to the Palace of Principle. She ascended the palace and went to the Chamber of the Grand Tower,

dn17:2.8.7.pli: Upasaṅkamitvā mahāviyūhassa kūṭāgārassa dvārabāhaṃ ālambitvā aṭṭhāsi.
dn17:2.8.7.eng: where she stood leaning against a door-post.

dn17:2.8.8.pli: Atha kho, ānanda, rājā mahāsudassano saddaṃ sutvā:

dn17:2.8.9.pli: ‘kiṃ nu kho mahato viya janakāyassa saddo’ti mahāviyūhā kūṭāgārā nikkhamanto addasa subhaddaṃ deviṃ dvārabāhaṃ ālambitvā ṭhitaṃ, disvāna subhaddaṃ deviṃ etadavoca:
dn17:2.8.9.eng: ‘What’s that, it sounds like a big crowd!’ Coming out of the chamber he saw Queen Subhaddā leaning against a door-post and said to her,

dn17:2.8.10.eng: ‘Please stay there, my queen, don’t enter in here.’
dn17:2.8.10.comm: He makes it clear that this will not be an intimate visit.

dn17:2.9.1.pli: Atha kho, ānanda, rājā mahāsudassano aññataraṃ purisaṃ āmantesi:
dn17:2.9.1.eng: Then he addressed a certain man,

dn17:2.9.2.pli: ‘ehi tvaṃ, ambho purisa, mahāviyūhā kūṭāgārā sovaṇṇamayaṃ pallaṅkaṃ nīharitvā sabbasovaṇṇamaye tālavane paññapehī’ti.
dn17:2.9.2.eng: ‘Come, mister, bring the golden couch from the Chamber of the Grand Tower and set it up in the golden palm grove.’

dn17:2.9.3.pli: ‘Evaṃ, devā’ti kho, ānanda, so puriso rañño mahāsudassanassa paṭissutvā mahāviyūhā kūṭāgārā sovaṇṇamayaṃ pallaṅkaṃ nīharitvā sabbasovaṇṇamaye tālavane paññapesi.
dn17:2.9.3.eng: ‘Yes, Your Majesty,’ that man replied, and did as he was asked.

dn17:2.9.4.pli: Atha kho, ānanda, rājā mahāsudassano dakkhiṇena passena sīhaseyyaṃ kappesi pāde pādaṃ accādhāya sato sampajāno.
dn17:2.9.4.eng: The king laid down in the lion’s posture—on the right side, placing one foot on top of the other—mindful and aware.

dn17:2.10.1.pli: Atha kho, ānanda, subhaddāya deviyā etadahosi:

dn17:2.10.2.pli: ‘vippasannāni kho rañño mahāsudassanassa indriyāni, parisuddho chavivaṇṇo pariyodāto, mā heva kho rājā mahāsudassano kālamakāsī’ti rājānaṃ mahāsudassanaṃ etadavoca:
dn17:2.10.2.eng: ‘The king’s faculties are so very clear, and the complexion of his skin is pure and bright. Let him not pass away!’ She said to him,
dn17:2.10.2.comm: The aorist is not past tense, as it is governed by mā.

dn17:2.10.3.eng: ‘Sire, you have 84,000 cities, with the royal capital of Kusāvatī foremost.

dn17:2.10.4.pli: Ettha, deva, chandaṃ janehi jīvite apekkhaṃ karohi.
dn17:2.10.4.eng: Arouse desire for these! Take an interest in life!’
dn17:2.10.4.comm: “Desire” is chanda, the first of the four bases of psychic power, which in DN 16:3.3.1 are said to lead to long life. By urging him to live long, she inverts the Mahāparinibbānasutta where Ānanda fails to do the same.

dn17:2.10.5.pli: Imāni te, deva, caturāsīti pāsādasahassāni dhammapāsādappamukhāni.
dn17:2.10.5.eng: And she likewise urged the king to live on by taking an interest in all his possessions as described above.

dn17:2.10.6.pli: Ettha, deva, chandaṃ janehi jīvite apekkhaṃ karohi.

dn17:2.10.7.pli: Imāni te, deva, caturāsīti kūṭāgārasahassāni mahāviyūhakūṭāgārappamukhāni.

dn17:2.10.8.pli: Ettha, deva, chandaṃ janehi jīvite apekkhaṃ karohi.

dn17:2.10.9.pli: Imāni te, deva, caturāsīti pallaṅkasahassāni sovaṇṇamayāni rūpiyamayāni dantamayāni sāramayāni gonakatthatāni paṭikatthatāni paṭalikatthatāni kadalimigapavarapaccattharaṇāni sauttaracchadāni ubhatolohitakūpadhānāni.

dn17:2.10.10.pli: Ettha, deva, chandaṃ janehi, jīvite apekkhaṃ karohi.

dn17:2.10.11.pli: Imāni te, deva, caturāsīti nāgasahassāni sovaṇṇālaṅkārāni sovaṇṇadhajāni hemajālapaṭicchannāni uposathanāgarājappamukhāni.

dn17:2.10.12.pli: Ettha, deva, chandaṃ janehi jīvite apekkhaṃ karohi.

dn17:2.10.13.pli: Imāni te, deva, caturāsīti assasahassāni sovaṇṇālaṅkārāni sovaṇṇadhajāni hemajālapaṭicchannāni valāhakaassarājappamukhāni.

dn17:2.10.14.pli: Ettha, deva, chandaṃ janehi jīvite apekkhaṃ karohi.

dn17:2.10.15.pli: Imāni te, deva, caturāsīti rathasahassāni sīhacammaparivārāni byagghacammaparivārāni dīpicammaparivārāni paṇḍukambalaparivārāni sovaṇṇālaṅkārāni sovaṇṇadhajāni hemajālapaṭicchannāni vejayantarathappamukhāni.

dn17:2.10.16.pli: Ettha, deva, chandaṃ janehi jīvite apekkhaṃ karohi.

dn17:2.10.17.pli: Imāni te, deva, caturāsīti maṇisahassāni maṇiratanappamukhāni.

dn17:2.10.18.pli: Ettha, deva, chandaṃ janehi jīvite apekkhaṃ karohi.

dn17:2.10.19.pli: Imāni te, deva, caturāsīti itthisahassāni itthiratanappamukhāni.

dn17:2.10.20.pli: Ettha, deva, chandaṃ janehi jīvite apekkhaṃ karohi.

dn17:2.10.21.pli: Imāni te, deva, caturāsīti gahapatisahassāni gahapatiratanappamukhāni.

dn17:2.10.22.pli: Ettha, deva, chandaṃ janehi jīvite apekkhaṃ karohi.

dn17:2.10.23.pli: Imāni te, deva, caturāsīti khattiyasahassāni anuyantāni pariṇāyakaratanappamukhāni.

dn17:2.10.24.pli: Ettha, deva, chandaṃ janehi jīvite apekkhaṃ karohi.

dn17:2.10.25.pli: Imāni te, deva, caturāsīti dhenusahassāni duhasandanāni kaṃsūpadhāraṇāni.

dn17:2.10.26.pli: Ettha, deva, chandaṃ janehi jīvite apekkhaṃ karohi.

dn17:2.10.27.pli: Imāni te, deva, caturāsīti vatthakoṭisahassāni khomasukhumānaṃ kappāsikasukhumānaṃ koseyyasukhumānaṃ kambalasukhumānaṃ.

dn17:2.10.28.pli: Ettha, deva, chandaṃ janehi, jīvite apekkhaṃ karohi.

dn17:2.10.29.pli: Imāni te, deva, caturāsīti thālipākasahassāni sāyaṃ pātaṃ bhattābhihāro abhihariyati.

dn17:2.10.30.pli: Ettha, deva, chandaṃ janehi jīvite apekkhaṃ karohī’ti.

dn17:2.11.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, ānanda, rājā mahāsudassano subhaddaṃ deviṃ etadavoca:
dn17:2.11.1.eng: When the queen had spoken, the king said to her,

dn17:2.11.2.pli: ‘Dīgharattaṃ kho maṃ tvaṃ, devi, iṭṭhehi kantehi piyehi manāpehi samudācarittha;
dn17:2.11.2.eng: ‘For a long time, my queen, you have spoken to me with words that are welcome, desirable, agreeable, and pleasant.

dn17:2.11.3.pli: atha ca pana maṃ tvaṃ pacchime kāle aniṭṭhehi akantehi appiyehi amanāpehi samudācarasī’ti.
dn17:2.11.3.eng: And yet in my final hour, your words are unwelcome, undesirable, disagreeable, and unpleasant!’
dn17:2.11.3.comm: Implying that Ānanda was right to not beg the Buddha to live long.

dn17:2.11.4.eng: ‘So how then, Your Majesty, am I to speak to you?’

dn17:2.11.6.pli: “sabbeheva, deva, piyehi manāpehi nānābhāvo vinābhāvo aññathābhāvo, mā kho tvaṃ, deva, sāpekkho kālamakāsi, dukkhā sāpekkhassa kālaṅkiriyā, garahitā ca sāpekkhassa kālaṅkiriyā.
dn17:2.11.6.eng: “Sire, we must be parted and separated from all we hold dear and beloved. Don’t pass away with concerns. Such concern is suffering, and it’s criticized.
dn17:2.11.6.comm: At AN 6.16:2.2 this advice is given by Nakula’s mother.

dn17:2.11.7.pli: Imāni te, deva, caturāsīti nagarasahassāni kusāvatīrājadhānippamukhāni.
dn17:2.11.7.eng: Sire, you have 84,000 cities, with the royal capital of Kusāvatī foremost.

dn17:2.11.8.pli: Ettha, deva, chandaṃ pajaha jīvite apekkhaṃ mākāsi.
dn17:2.11.8.eng: Give up desire for these! Take no interest in life!”’

dn17:2.11.9.pli: Imāni te, deva, caturāsīti pāsādasahassāni dhammapāsādappamukhāni.
dn17:2.11.9.eng: And so on for all the king’s possessions.

dn17:2.11.10.pli: Ettha, deva, chandaṃ pajaha jīvite apekkhaṃ mākāsi.

dn17:2.11.11.pli: Imāni te, deva, caturāsīti kūṭāgārasahassāni mahāviyūhakūṭāgārappamukhāni.

dn17:2.11.12.pli: Ettha, deva, chandaṃ pajaha jīvite apekkhaṃ mākāsi.

dn17:2.11.13.pli: Imāni te, deva, caturāsīti pallaṅkasahassāni sovaṇṇamayāni rūpiyamayāni dantamayāni sāramayāni gonakatthatāni paṭikatthatāni paṭalikatthatāni kadalimigapavarapaccattharaṇāni sauttaracchadāni ubhatolohitakūpadhānāni.

dn17:2.11.14.pli: Ettha, deva, chandaṃ pajaha jīvite apekkhaṃ mākāsi.

dn17:2.11.15.pli: Imāni te, deva, caturāsīti nāgasahassāni sovaṇṇālaṅkārāni sovaṇṇadhajāni hemajālapaṭicchannāni uposathanāgarājappamukhāni.

dn17:2.11.16.pli: Ettha, deva, chandaṃ pajaha jīvite apekkhaṃ mākāsi.

dn17:2.11.17.pli: Imāni te, deva, caturāsīti assasahassāni sovaṇṇālaṅkārāni sovaṇṇadhajāni hemajālapaṭicchannāni valāhakaassarājappamukhāni.

dn17:2.11.18.pli: Ettha, deva, chandaṃ pajaha jīvite apekkhaṃ mākāsi.

dn17:2.11.19.pli: Imāni te, deva, caturāsīti rathasahassāni sīhacammaparivārāni byagghacammaparivārāni dīpicammaparivārāni paṇḍukambalaparivārāni sovaṇṇālaṅkārāni sovaṇṇadhajāni hemajālapaṭicchannāni vejayantarathappamukhāni.

dn17:2.12.1.eng: When the king had spoken, Queen Subhaddā cried and burst out in tears.

dn17:2.12.2.pli: Atha kho, ānanda, subhaddā devī assūni puñchitvā rājānaṃ mahāsudassanaṃ etadavoca:
dn17:2.12.2.eng: Wiping away her tears, the queen said to the king:

dn17:2.12.3.pli: ‘Sabbeheva, deva, piyehi manāpehi nānābhāvo vinābhāvo aññathābhāvo, mā kho tvaṃ, deva, sāpekkho kālamakāsi, dukkhā sāpekkhassa kālaṅkiriyā, garahitā ca sāpekkhassa kālaṅkiriyā.
dn17:2.12.3.eng: ‘Sire, we must be parted and separated from all we hold dear and beloved. Don’t pass away with concerns. Such concern is suffering, and it’s criticized.

dn17:2.12.4.pli: Imāni te, deva, caturāsīti nagarasahassāni kusāvatīrājadhānippamukhāni.
dn17:2.12.4.eng: Sire, you have 84,000 cities, with the royal capital of Kusāvatī foremost.

dn17:2.12.5.pli: Ettha, deva, chandaṃ pajaha jīvite apekkhaṃ mākāsi.
dn17:2.12.5.eng: Give up desire for these! Take no interest in life!’

dn17:2.13.0.eng: 8. Rebirth in the Realm of Divinity

dn17:2.13.1.pli: Atha kho, ānanda, rājā mahāsudassano na cirasseva kālamakāsi.
dn17:2.13.1.eng: Not long after that, King Mahāsudassana passed away.

dn17:2.13.2.pli: Seyyathāpi, ānanda, gahapatissa vā gahapatiputtassa vā manuññaṃ bhojanaṃ bhuttāvissa bhattasammado hoti; evameva kho, ānanda, rañño mahāsudassanassa māraṇantikā vedanā ahosi.
dn17:2.13.2.eng: And the feeling he had close to death was like a householder or their child falling asleep after eating a satisfying meal.
dn17:2.13.2.comm: This contrasts with the Buddha’s last meal at DN 16:4.20.1, which caused sickness and distress. The Buddha was rejecting existence entirely, whereas Mahāsudassana was continuing in a pleasant form of conditioned existence.

dn17:2.13.3.pli: Kālaṅkato ca, ānanda, rājā mahāsudassano sugatiṃ brahmalokaṃ upapajji.
dn17:2.13.3.eng: When he passed away King Mahāsudassana was reborn in a good place, a realm of divinity.

dn17:2.13.4.pli: Rājā, ānanda, mahāsudassano caturāsīti vassasahassāni kumārakīḷaṃ kīḷi.
dn17:2.13.4.eng: Ānanda, King Mahāsudassana played children’s games for 84,000 years.

dn17:2.13.5.eng: He ruled as viceroy for 84,000 years.

dn17:2.13.6.eng: He ruled as king for 84,000 years.

dn17:2.13.7.pli: Caturāsīti vassasahassāni gihibhūto dhamme pāsāde brahmacariyaṃ cari.
dn17:2.13.7.eng: He led the spiritual life as a layman in the Palace of Principle for 84,000 years.

dn17:2.13.8.pli: So cattāro brahmavihāre bhāvetvā kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā brahmalokūpago ahosi.
dn17:2.13.8.eng: And having developed the four divine meditations, when his body broke up, after death, he was reborn in a good place, a realm of divinity.

dn17:2.14.2.pli: ‘añño nūna tena samayena rājā mahāsudassano ahosī’ti,
dn17:2.14.2.eng: ‘Surely King Mahāsudassana must have been someone else at that time?’

dn17:2.14.3.pli: na kho panetaṃ, ānanda, evaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ. Ahaṃ tena samayena rājā mahāsudassano ahosiṃ.
dn17:2.14.3.eng: But you should not see it like that. I myself was King Mahāsudassana at that time.
dn17:2.14.3.comm: After DN 5:21.16, this is the second Jātaka in the Dīghanikāya.

dn17:2.14.4.pli: Mama tāni caturāsīti nagarasahassāni kusāvatīrājadhānippamukhāni, mama tāni caturāsīti pāsādasahassāni dhammapāsādappamukhāni, mama tāni caturāsīti kūṭāgārasahassāni mahāviyūhakūṭāgārappamukhāni, mama tāni caturāsīti pallaṅkasahassāni sovaṇṇamayāni rūpiyamayāni dantamayāni sāramayāni gonakatthatāni paṭikatthatāni paṭalikatthatāni kadalimigapavarapaccattharaṇāni sauttaracchadāni ubhatolohitakūpadhānāni, mama tāni caturāsīti nāgasahassāni sovaṇṇālaṅkārāni sovaṇṇadhajāni hemajālapaṭicchannāni uposathanāgarājappamukhāni, mama tāni caturāsīti assasahassāni sovaṇṇālaṅkārāni sovaṇṇadhajāni hemajālapaṭicchannāni valāhakaassarājappamukhāni, mama tāni caturāsīti rathasahassāni sīhacammaparivārāni byagghacammaparivārāni dīpicammaparivārāni paṇḍukambalaparivārāni sovaṇṇālaṅkārāni sovaṇṇadhajāni hemajālapaṭicchannāni vejayantarathappamukhāni, mama tāni caturāsīti maṇisahassāni maṇiratanappamukhāni, mama tāni caturāsīti itthisahassāni subhaddādevippamukhāni, mama tāni caturāsīti gahapatisahassāni gahapatiratanappamukhāni, mama tāni caturāsīti khattiyasahassāni anuyantāni pariṇāyakaratanappamukhāni, mama tāni caturāsīti dhenusahassāni duhasandanāni kaṃsūpadhāraṇāni, mama tāni caturāsīti vatthakoṭisahassāni khomasukhumānaṃ kappāsikasukhumānaṃ koseyyasukhumānaṃ kambalasukhumānaṃ, mama tāni caturāsīti thālipākasahassāni sāyaṃ pātaṃ bhattābhihāro abhihariyittha.
dn17:2.14.4.eng: Mine were the 84,000 cities, with the royal capital of Kusāvatī foremost. And mine were all the other possessions.

dn17:2.15.1.pli: Tesaṃ kho panānanda, caturāsītinagarasahassānaṃ ekaññeva taṃ nagaraṃ hoti, yaṃ tena samayena ajjhāvasāmi yadidaṃ kusāvatī rājadhānī.
dn17:2.15.1.eng: Of those 84,000 cities, I only stayed in one, the capital Kusāvatī.

dn17:2.15.2.pli: Tesaṃ kho panānanda, caturāsīti pāsādasahassānaṃ ekoyeva so pāsādo hoti, yaṃ tena samayena ajjhāvasāmi yadidaṃ dhammo pāsādo.
dn17:2.15.2.eng: Of those 84,000 palaces, I only dwelt in one, the Palace of Principle.

dn17:2.15.3.pli: Tesaṃ kho panānanda, caturāsīti kūṭāgārasahassānaṃ ekaññeva taṃ kūṭāgāraṃ hoti, yaṃ tena samayena ajjhāvasāmi yadidaṃ mahāviyūhaṃ kūṭāgāraṃ.
dn17:2.15.3.eng: Of those 84,000 chambers, I only dwelt in the Chamber of the Grand Tower.

dn17:2.15.4.pli: Tesaṃ kho panānanda, caturāsīti pallaṅkasahassānaṃ ekoyeva so pallaṅko hoti, yaṃ tena samayena paribhuñjāmi yadidaṃ sovaṇṇamayo vā rūpiyamayo vā dantamayo vā sāramayo vā.
dn17:2.15.4.eng: Of those 84,000 couches, I only used one, made of gold or silver or ivory or heartwood.

dn17:2.15.5.pli: Tesaṃ kho panānanda, caturāsīti nāgasahassānaṃ ekoyeva so nāgo hoti, yaṃ tena samayena abhiruhāmi yadidaṃ uposatho nāgarājā.
dn17:2.15.5.eng: Of those 84,000 bull elephants, I only rode one, the royal bull elephant named Sabbath.

dn17:2.15.6.pli: Tesaṃ kho panānanda, caturāsīti assasahassānaṃ ekoyeva so asso hoti, yaṃ tena samayena abhiruhāmi yadidaṃ valāhako assarājā.
dn17:2.15.6.eng: Of those 84,000 horses, I only rode one, the royal horse named Thundercloud.

dn17:2.15.7.pli: Tesaṃ kho panānanda, caturāsīti rathasahassānaṃ ekoyeva so ratho hoti, yaṃ tena samayena abhiruhāmi yadidaṃ vejayantaratho.
dn17:2.15.7.eng: Of those 84,000 chariots, I only rode one, the chariot named Triumph.

dn17:2.15.8.pli: Tesaṃ kho panānanda, caturāsīti itthisahassānaṃ ekāyeva sā itthī hoti, yā tena samayena paccupaṭṭhāti khattiyānī vā vessinī vā.
dn17:2.15.8.eng: Of those 84,000 women, I was only served by one, an aristocrat maiden or a coquette.
dn17:2.15.8.comm: Readings here and at SN 22.96:4.8 are confused, and further complicated at Tha Ap 411:4.1. I read  velāsikā due to the passage’s similarity DN 23:15.4, where a “coquette” is also serving a royal. I believe the variant velāmikā_ is a ghost word contaminated from AN 9.20:4.1.

dn17:2.15.9.pli: Tesaṃ kho panānanda, caturāsīti vatthakoṭisahassānaṃ ekaṃyeva taṃ dussayugaṃ hoti, yaṃ tena samayena paridahāmi khomasukhumaṃ vā kappāsikasukhumaṃ vā koseyyasukhumaṃ vā kambalasukhumaṃ vā.
dn17:2.15.9.eng: Of those 8,400,000,000 cloths, I only wore one pair, made of delicate linen, cotton, silk, or wool.

dn17:2.15.10.pli: Tesaṃ kho panānanda, caturāsīti thālipākasahassānaṃ ekoyeva so thālipāko hoti, yato nāḷikodanaparamaṃ bhuñjāmi tadupiyañca sūpeyyaṃ.
dn17:2.15.10.eng: Of those 84,000 servings of food, I only had one, eating at most a cup of rice with suitable sauce.

dn17:2.16.1.pli: Passānanda, sabbete saṅkhārā atītā niruddhā vipariṇatā.
dn17:2.16.1.eng: See, Ānanda! All those conditioned phenomena have passed, ceased, and perished.

dn17:2.16.5.pli: Yāvañcidaṃ, ānanda, alameva sabbasaṅkhāresu nibbindituṃ, alaṃ virajjituṃ, alaṃ vimuccituṃ.
dn17:2.16.5.eng: This is quite enough for you to become disillusioned, dispassionate, and freed regarding all conditions.

dn17:2.17.1.pli: Chakkhattuṃ kho panāhaṃ, ānanda, abhijānāmi imasmiṃ padese sarīraṃ nikkhipitaṃ, tañca kho rājāva samāno cakkavattī dhammiko dhammarājā cāturanto vijitāvī janapadatthāvariyappatto sattaratanasamannāgato, ayaṃ sattamo sarīranikkhepo.
dn17:2.17.1.eng: Six times, Ānanda, I recall having laid down my body at this place. And the seventh time was as a wheel-turning monarch, a just and principled king, at which time my dominion extended to all four sides, I achieved stability in the country, and I possessed the seven treasures.

dn17:2.17.2.pli: Na kho panāhaṃ, ānanda, taṃ padesaṃ samanupassāmi sadevake loke samārake sabrahmake sassamaṇabrāhmaṇiyā pajāya sadevamanussāya yattha tathāgato aṭṭhamaṃ sarīraṃ nikkhipeyyā”ti.
dn17:2.17.2.eng: But Ānanda, I do not see any place in this world with its gods, Māras, and Divinities, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, its gods and humans where the Realized One would lay down his body for the eighth time.”

dn17:2.17.3.eng: That is what the Buddha said.

dn17:2.17.4.pli: Idaṃ vatvāna sugato athāparaṃ etadavoca satthā:
dn17:2.17.4.eng: Then the Holy One, the Teacher, went on to say:

dn17:2.17.6.eng: their nature is to rise and fall;
